item.name: 10 Days in the USA
item.comment: It's just bland for me. I can see why others might like it, but just setting out a board and not putting anything on it is just freaky. Besides, Ticket to Ride seems to fit the "route-building" urge in me just fine.

item.name: 2 de Mayo
item.comment: What a delightful mix of guesswork and area control. Excellent, quick-playing two-player game that is very unique and a blast to play.
Come to America, please. EXCELLENT game. See my review. *Update* - Thanks Mikey for the birthday present! Love the tension of this one.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: Okay, there's a learning curve here. For an experienced gamer, though, it's only about one game. After the first game I knew everything I had to know and started to work on trying different strategies. It was around that second play that I really fell in love with it. Gorgeous game that plays really, really well. I can't believe such an involved game can play seven people in 30 minutes, but it can. This is one of the best games of the year, no doubt. *Update* - 13 plays later and it's made my 10 list. Absolutely love it.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Catan
item.comment: Fun, thematic board. The destroy-two-coins from others is just NASTY. The trading idea is also very cool.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Leaders
item.comment: Absolutely love it. Leaders makes the game even more fun and I don't see why I won't be playing with it every time I pull 7 Wonders out. Doesn't add to the length or difficulty at all, just more fun!

item.name: 7 Wonders: Manneken Pis
item.comment: A worthy addition to one of my favorite games. As far as I'm concerned I'd like to have 50 boards to use.

item.name: A B Seas
item.comment: I think this is an excellent game for 3-5 year-olds. A good example of an alphabet game done right -- excellent components and really helps to involve the kids.

item.name: A Fool's Fortune
item.comment: There's a solid game here, but it's not unique in feel at all, and the theme is close to non-existent. Pretty pictures and quick, and lots of options for depth, but I'm just not finding myself engaged enough to want to play again.

item.name: A la carte
item.comment: Great little set collection/dexterity game with absolutely FANTASTIC components. Fun for kids of all ages.

item.name: Abandon Ship
item.comment: One of the top surprises of the year for me. I knew the kids would enjoy it, but I'm finding it working with both kids and adults, all through the gamet of player numbers. It's just fun, and great to roll dice too. The decisions presented are enough to keep interested as well. Fun!

item.name: Abyss
item.comment: Abyss is indeed a gorgeous game. I would not say the MOST gorgeous I have played, but it is very, very well put-together. Aside from looks, the game is solid. I could play Abyss many times before refusing a play. The interaction provided with the pearls makes for a fun, tense game that has you work a strategy and hope that you can keep it going. Great game.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: It's truly amazing how this design still stands up to today. A game that is 50 years old! I still like the reimplementations of the system better (Lords of Vegas) but it's still fun to play and it is a true classic of gaming.

item.name: Ad Astra
item.comment: Some neat ideas that mimic Settlers and allowing the game to feel quite different. I'd call it "advanced" Starfarers.

item.name: The Adventurers: The Temple of Chac
item.comment: Four plays through and I've played with two players all the way up through 6. While it's definitely a better game with more players, I'm starting to see how there is some replayability problems. Sure, expansions are being made, but I wonder if the game itself is good enough to invest the $60+ into it. I've also found the game a little difficult to teach as it's a bit fiddly with mechanics that require you to roll a '3 or less' here and a '4 or more' there.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: It took me a play to learn what the heck I should be doing, and then it took me another play to figure out if this is for me or not. Well, I STILL can't say. I need another play. Regardless, I don't see it topping my Top 50 anytime soon, if ever. The theme is certainly there, it's just not a theme I enjoy. *update* I have found that I actually enjoy the iOS version much more than the cardboard. Rarely happens but I would rate it through iOS a 7.5

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
item.comment: Fantastic small viewing of the larger, much longer game. Plays quickly and has a good amount of variety in each game, provided the expansion is purchased. I'd call it an essential expansion. Could end up being my favorite two-player game in the end.

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small – More Buildings Big and Small
item.comment: Not much to add here except its essential to get at least one of the expansions for this fantastic game.

item.name: Airlines Europe
item.comment: Surprised to find how much I enjoyed this. While that might have something to do with the awesome little plastic planes, I think the gameplay is terrific and it's by far and away my favorite stock game to date.

item.name: Airships
item.comment: Neat dice-rolling game that's a bit different from the norm. Good gateway game, a hit from 2-4 players. *Update* Now after a few plays, I'm starting to sour a bit. When you roll bad it seems like it's just a horrible thing, even with the token.

item.name: Alea Iacta Est
item.comment: Clever ideas and a good filler, but a horrible name choice. Assigning dice to different regions and then working on a set collection idea makes for a pretty good game, though.

item.name: Alfredo's Food Fight
item.comment: Cute game, great components, just not that much to keep you interested.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment: I guess it kind of works well, but I don't find this very inspiring at all. Something about it just doesn't flow for me, whether it is niggling issues about the production or gameflow, I'm not sure. I also don't like how they put six pawns in the game and expect the game to play well at 6, which I can only imagine would be a nightmare. Anyway, there are too many great games out there to waste my time with this one. *Update* - Played once more with the Anniversary Edition and the upgraded component quality does add into my decision to raise from a 5 to a 6. Also, the game left a better impression from my first few times. I still think it's a 3-4 player game, though, as while the dummy player is not as big as annoyance as some, I still don't like it.

item.name: Alhambra: The Dice Game
item.comment: Fun, but needs to play about 3-4 players to be fun, and that's the problem. It just goes too long for what it is.

item.name: Alien Frontiers
item.comment: Just received, blown away at the quality of this game. What a fabulous experience. I love every second of it. Three plays through so far and it's a 9, and I can totally see this reaching my 10 spot eventually. *Update* - Yup! A 10. I absolutely love it.

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Factions
item.comment: I enjoy factions as a sometimes variant to Alien Frontiers. I've played the base game 12 times and still enthralled, but factions adds just enough to keep the fun around longer.

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Outer Belt
item.comment: Non-essential, but changes the game in a fun way and good to have for variety if you plan on keeping AF around.

item.name: All Wound Up
item.comment: Fantastic idea for a theme and mechanics. Unfortunately, implementation was the pits and sometimes those darn zombies just don't cooperate like they should.

item.name: Ambush!
item.comment: I've been anticipating this game for quite a while, years in the making really. I've been intimidated by the "oldness" of everything, though, and just recently got through the rulebook and spunked up to play. And after the first mission, I now know that I would have played this every day of my life back in the 80s if I knew about it. Looking forward to playing some more missions with my guys before rating. Absolutely GENIUS system, and I can't imagine how long it took to write up that storybook.

item.name: Amerigo
item.comment: Would like to play this more. I think this is one of Feld's better games, and it seems to have flew under the radar. But really, it's not too complicated and I like the gimmick tower.

item.name: Amun-Re
item.comment: Thanks Udvardis/David for this great birthday present! And now that I know what I'm doing I think I'll start to figure it out. It does take a few plays to get down the overall idea of the game. I'm not sure that I'm TOO crazy about how it works, though. I can recognize that it's a very well-designed game, but I'm not crazy about it (yet).

item.name: Ancient Terrible Things
item.comment: Fun version of Yahtzee with some really neat choices and item purchasing. I enjoyed it quite a bit. Curious about the expansion and would like to play again.

item.name: Angry Birds: Knock on Wood
item.comment: Fun dexterity element, and while the rules certainly aren't developed to a superb level, I love the theme and the components. The kids enjoy it too!

item.name: Animal Upon Animal
item.comment: Excellent stacking game and it's really for all ages. As far as stacking games go, it's the best I've seen yet.

item.name: Anomia
item.comment: Clever party game with not a lot of replayability.

item.name: Antler Island
item.comment: Excellent family-style game with some great theme. You can play the game with both kids and adults, but chances are what comes out of your mouth will be quite different in both games! Rules and layout are intuitive and very easy to understand and have fun with. Great production! *Update* - Now that I've played three times I realize that the first half of the game is really quite pointless. Things only get interesting when you're getting close to the end and trying to figure out how to stop the leader from winning. So I would say it's good for a few laughs and at this point it's probably ready to trot away to find someone else to rut!

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment: 10+ plays through A&A, and I'm starting to tire of it. I'll still play it, of course, and it's a highly-requested favorite at gatherings. I imagine it's time to take a step up to Say Anything, and I will, eventually. Still get some laughs, still a great vocabulary-building game for the kids.

item.name: Apples to Apples Junior
item.comment: Good addition to give the kids some more chances at words that they understand and can therefore use appropriately. Unfortunately, I truly believe that A2A is a flawed game, but still a good one for the non-gamer.

item.name: Aquaretto
item.comment: Having already played Zooloretto, this game is VERY similar. So of course the first thing I was looking for was which mechanics were different. I have to admit I didn't like most of them -- the stacking in the pen was odd to search through for opponents, and I really didn't like the expandable boards either. One thing that was terrific were the meeples and their abilities, definitely the best part of the game. Why are the fields grass? Should have been water. Either way, buy Zooloretto instead.

item.name: Arcadia Quest
item.comment: A fun, full of character battle game that has a lot of flavor. It would play well with adults and kids alike. I played a painted copy, which added to the luster. Excited to see what the future holds for this game and its series, and would love a copy of my own.

item.name: Arcane Legions
item.comment: This game is looking unloved on the Geek and I can't understand it. The tray is a wonderful and inventive idea, and a joy to play with. Instead of a roll-and-shoot mentality, I feel like there's some strategy to this one. Geeks, you need to give this one a shot.

item.name: Archaeology: The Card Game
item.comment: I really like this little game -- puts some variety on Bohnanza and it's so quick.

item.name: Are You the Traitor?
item.comment: I found it a bit underwhelming, and for a short BSG-feel, The Resistance is such a better choice.

item.name: The Ark of the Covenant
item.comment: I'm not positive that this has enough variation for me to keep it along with its big brother (sister?) I do like moving the Ark very much, but I'm thinking that mechanic could easily be put into the original game. And I think it pales in comparison to Hunters & Gatherers, and the original.

item.name: Arkadia
item.comment: Every time it comes out I'm enjoying it, and I also find myself recommending it as well. A good abstract, as it finds a way to incorporate a "board game" element to it as well. *Update* - traded, as I hadn't played it in quite some time.

item.name: Asara
item.comment: Light euro that I enjoyed but not particularly excited about. Certainly right up my alley, but perhaps not enough differences or mechanics to warrant me wanting my own copy.

item.name: Ascending Empires
item.comment: Now we're talking! Civ building with flicking usually would reel me in, but after a play I gotta have it. The guys that design these things are geniuses. Really enjoyed the aspects of picking a tree to level and then flicking my ships to explore and attack. Can't wait to play again. *Update* Played a few more times and something is bugging me. The ideas are genius but it goes too long for what I want it to be and the mining mechanic really bugs me. I actually wish the flicking was a bigger part of the game.

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Pathwarden Promo
item.comment: Hard to rate as it's just one card and rarely sees the light of day. He might be a bit overcosted but most likely useful.

item.name: Ascension: Deckbuilding Game
item.comment: I've always liked Dominion -- Ascension to me is perhaps not the better game, but I find it to be more fun to play. The art and theme are fabulous and the mechanics of the factions and the center row are very enjoyable to me. Steadily on the rise as one of my favorites. *Update* After 10 plays, I still enjoy Ascension, but I did have to lower my rating to an 8. It doesn't have a lot of depth to it, so maybe there's an expansion that can help that. *Update* From what I've seen from the expansion, I'm not pleased.

item.name: Ascension: Return of the Fallen
item.comment: Return of the Fallen is very, very similar to CotG -- with a few tweaks here and there. It feels like you can be more powerful, and in that instance, I think I like RotF a little bit better than the original.

item.name: Ascension: Theme Pack – Rat King
item.comment: A worthy addition -- although there is the possibility of it becoming a huge game-changer, especially in a two-player game.

item.name: Asteroyds
item.comment: It's kind of like Roborally in space, but in a lot less time. We played with a guy that has incredible skills and never made one mistake. I made plenty. It's a fun game!

item.name: AT-43 Initiation Set: Operation Damocles
item.comment: I have a bunch of Red Blok stuff -- looking forward to playing this more. The system is straight-forward enough and still provides some good tactics/strategy.

item.name: Atlantis Rising
item.comment: I like the simplicity of this game. The presentation, art, and mechanics are all pretty great! Easy to learn and teach. Freaking hard game, have yet to win in two tries. I'm a little worried about repeated play, because it might feel a bit samey after a while. But enjoying it so far!

item.name: Attika
item.comment: A very clever, pretty game with some neat mechanics that inspire you heavily where you go. With repeated plays, I can see my rating advancing on this one. Too bad it is so difficult to find. If I had first played it in 2003, no doubt I would have initially rated it an 8 or higher.

item.name: Augustus
item.comment: It certainly works, and once you get past the Bingo mechanic there is some enjoyment here. But I won't have any problems going through the rest of my life without playing Augustus again.

item.name: Ave Caesar
item.comment: A solid race game, probably one of the best of its genre. I enjoy the theme as well, and the art and chariots are quite nice. I did find it interesting that the person that started out first ended up winning also.

item.name: The Awful Green Things From Outer Space
item.comment: So far, I enjoyed the game and the concept but the endgame and it's horrid randomness really left me hurting. I desire another play before I rate. *Update* - the endgame got to me.

item.name: Axis & Allies
item.comment: Good childhood memories. Played it a good amount of times when smaller.

item.name: Balderdash
item.comment: Pretty fun, but it doesn't come close to entertaining me like some of my other favorite party games.

item.name: Balloon Cup
item.comment:
My wife and I enjoy this on occasion -- I feel like it runs on a bit longer than it should at times, but it's a fun exercise in math and evil. Yup, I said evil -- you can really mess someone up in this game!
*Update* - played with the designer's rules of not being able to play any cards on your opponent until you fill up your side first. I'm not sure this is a good idea, in fact, it might be broken. It causes a lot of situations where you either put a card on your side that hurts you, or makes you discard your hand hoping to find something that you can play.

item.name: BANG!
item.comment: It's a no for me -- it has a few things I don't like, such as player elimination and those random card draws when you really need to have something to use. But back in 2002, I'd probably have thought it was great gaming. Things have just gotten so much better.

item.name: BANG! The Dice Game
item.comment: I'll admit, I originally thought this game sucked. I don't care for it with more than 5. But 4-5, I enjoyed it for what it was. Considering purchase. I like the player power interaction with the dice very much.

item.name: Basari
item.comment: I enjoyed this one a lot to start -- easy to teach and play, and the bartering and light thinking is fun. But it does have a runaway-leader issue, and this edition from Out of the Box is quite ugly. I'd like to get the German edition sometime.

item.name: Baseball Highlights: 2045
item.comment: Here's a game that came out of nowhere for me. I love baseball, so that was enough for purchase. But you don't quite get the rules until you play. Once you grasp what's going on, you come to realize how incredible this game is. Truly has a shot to be one of the best 2-player games and might be my favorite game of 2015.

item.name: Baseball Highlights: 2045 – Hitters Expansion
item.comment: Nice variety to make a great game great.

item.name: Baseball Highlights: 2045 – Magna Glove Expansion
item.comment: Nice variety to make a great game great.

item.name: Baseball Highlights: 2045 – Pitchers Expansion
item.comment: Nice variety to make a great game great.

item.name: The Battle at Kemble's Cascade
item.comment: I was nonplussed. I was hoping the mechanic would just work better than it did. The disconnect in my head won't go away. Maybe it's just not for me, which I'm ok with. Happy to have played. Also, it's a bit clunky.

item.name: Battle Beyond Space
item.comment: Wacky enough of a title to want to keep due to its uniqueness. I can't say the game is pure quality, but it is a kick.

item.name: Battle Cry
item.comment: Terrific civil war game with my favorite war system of all time. I had already discovered Memoir and Battlelore before BC, and I would place this one right in the middle of them as far as enjoyment goes. The generals are a neat touch, and the weapons are all very realistic as far as their stats and strategy. Love that the infantry is so powerful (and rightly so). Really, there's not much different here than with the new updated version, so I went ahead and bought this one for a great deal.

item.name: Battle Cry: 150th Civil War Anniversary Edition
item.comment: Another excellent adaptation of the system. I am truly impressed with Richard Borg to be able to take the same freaking system and make it feel so different every time. I find it interesting that most people have said this was easier than the Memoir system -- I found it to have just as many difficult decisions and I LOVED the different feel of the game. Terrific.

item.name: The Battle for Hill 218
item.comment: Simulates an abstract well and the mechanics aren't terrible, but we felt it was just too dry.

item.name: Battle Line
item.comment: I've played this enough times to where I feel like I should be able to understand it better than I do. I know it's supposed to be a simple game to get, I just don't get it. I don't find it as fun as others. But for those that like it, what an excellent value for $10. *Update* - two years later, I played it again and found it a solid game.

item.name: Battle Masters
item.comment: Once a favorite of my youth, now a favorite of my son. The box is so big it's stored under the bed! I would imagine I played this sucker at least ten to twenty times in my youth.

item.name: The Battle of Red Cliffs
item.comment: I'm not sure I'm a huge fan of this type of game. I am not familiar with the game that it is based on, either. But, I did enjoy it for what it was. I played it with a group of 10 people, and it handled it quite well and quickly to boot. The artwork is gorgeous as well.
item.conditiontext: Great condition. Comes with expansion card.

item.name: Battle of the Sexes
item.comment: Geez, this game was really, really poor.

item.name: Battleball
item.comment: One of my son's favorites, I enjoy it as well -- especially with the Advanced rules.

item.name: Battleground
item.comment: Seems quite fiddly at first play, not sure how I like adding and subtracting all those multipliers and add-ons. The game itself seems to work okay. Need another play. I used the Undead and Lizardmen armies.

item.name: BattleLore
item.comment: I really love this system. I find it engaging and very enjoyable -- and the Lore pushes the game over the top.

item.name: BattleLore (Second Edition)
item.comment: I want to LOVE Battlelore 2nd. Something is holding me back -- can't place my finger on it. Maybe it's that there is no defined missions -- something about the random event setup, and the Fog of War setup. I love the game and the universe so I should have this up to 8 or 9 by now, but it's not there yet. Grrrrrrr! I will say that I enjoyed the iOS port quite a bit.

item.name: BattleLore: Call to Arms
item.comment: Haven't really gotten into this concept -- I see the value and purpose, but I just don't think the game needs it.

item.name: BattleLore: Dwarven Battalion Specialist Pack
item.comment: The dwarf pack is an essential add-on to Battlelore. They're tough!

item.name: BattleLore: Epic BattleLore
item.comment: The best thing for me about Epic BattleLore, is that when you play it it feels like you're on a grander scale, but the time of the game doesn't really increase by much if you're playing two players. Very, very awesome.

item.name: BattleLore: For Troll and Country
item.comment: The Troll is my favorite creature so far, and these maps aren't bad at all. I think people had trouble with the price point to start, of course, I got this for a song so I think it's great.

item.name: BattleLore: Goblin Marauders Specialist Pack
item.comment: The better of the two goblin packs in that this gives you your ostriches. Both packs give you the band, so its essential to buy one.

item.name: BattleLore: Goblin Skirmishers Specialist Pack
item.comment: The slingers in here don't do much to your force, so I'd recommend buying Marauders if you're going to buy just one. Both packs give you the band, so its essential to buy one.

item.name: Battleship Live
item.comment: Good for a run or two, if it worked correctly!

item.name: Battlestar Galactica
item.comment: What a terrific experience game! I do have some issues with it, but the system is so incredible I find it hard to complain. It's such a blast to play. It's great for a fan of the series like I am to get into character as well. Whenever there's a long gameday to be had, I want to play it. Almost always generates a memorable experience!

item.name: Bausack
item.comment: Very interested in 'Bausack' version as I have played the Bandu version. It's shape-stacking at its finest.

item.name: Bazaar
item.comment: Happy to have played, but this gemtrading Sackson game is nothing to write home about.

item.name: Bears!
item.comment: See my review -- neat idea but just don't see it holding up at all.

item.name: Belfort
item.comment: Excellent mix of several games I enjoy, like Stone Age, and the production is outstanding. Josh Cappel does the art and again blows it out of this world. The only downside is that there is a pretty good amount of downtime in a 4-to-5 player game. Still, a winner.

item.name: Beowulf: The Legend
item.comment: This game really reminds me of Knizia's Lord of the Rings, and for that reason alone I enjoy it, as I am a fan of the card system used in that game. Still looking forward to playing with a host of folks opposed to 2. I would imagine it really shines with 3-5.

item.name: Beowulf: The Movie Board Game
item.comment: Very fun with two players. A drag with any more. One of my favorite "mathy" games.

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment: Very clever ideas, pure American-style game for sure. It's an experience game, and I think it delivers a terrific experience when you're in the mood for that. Not very happy with the quality of the re-print, though.

item.name: Biblios
item.comment: Good filler with drafting mechanic that worked quite well and was fun and easy to learn.

item.name: The Big Fat Tomato Game
item.comment: I don't know. Just don't see this getting pulled out with any regularity.

item.name: The Big Idea
item.comment: I think this one is pretty far behind Snake Oil and But Wait! There's More ..

item.name: BITS
item.comment: Interesting and different-enough take on FITS, this time around using colors and shapes both. Scratches that FITS itch quite well with some new twists.

item.name: Black Fleet
item.comment: Black Fleet was a fun one-and-done for me. I like the family game aspect of it and how you're never truly "eliminated" from winning. But it wasn't good enough for me to enjoy repeated plays.

item.name: Blast Off
item.comment: No soul in this one to consider keeping.

item.name: Blockade Runner
item.comment: Neat ideas with an ugly presentation. Overall it's a good game, but the luck surrounding your ships surviving is just too much for me to actually enjoy the game on a further play basis. Still, an enjoyable first play. I do like dice!

item.name: Blokus
item.comment: Well, this was better than I expected. Our 4-player games have been very enjoyable!

item.name: Blokus Duo
item.comment: Two-player Blokus is really where it's at. I love this version.

item.name: Blokus Trigon
item.comment: Okay, but I much prefer either the two-player Blokus or regular Blokus.

item.name: Blood Bowl: Team Manager – The Card Game
item.comment: A few things about this one that I found interesting. First, I don't care for football very much, but the appeal of this game is not necessarily to football fans. In fact, there's not much resembling actually playing a football game. You play to situations and you try to gain the most fans, not score the most points. And you do that with a deck of cards for each team that feel very different between them, and each have different strategies. The concept, to me, is out of the park good. We've played it three times so far, and each time has been enjoyable. Quick setup time and a good deal of fun in less than an hour. Looking forward to playing multiplayer.

item.name: Blue Moon City
item.comment: Excellent game that I imagine becomes even more fun after playing through a few times and getting the symbols down pat.

item.name: Bobbin' Bumblebee
item.comment: Fun dexterity! Big hit with the kids. I wish things were made with just a bit better quality, though, as the plastic felt a bit cheap.

item.name: La Boca
item.comment: A delightful puzzle game that gives a shot at the team game as well. I've always thought that this would be a good one and I was not let down. Its system is perfect.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: Great with 2-4 -- excellent gateway game, very fun.

item.name: Bombay
item.comment: Pick-up and delivery in India with some of the coolest component action ever. I really like this game and it has held up for me in repeated plays.

item.name: Bootleggers
item.comment: Very thematic and engaging -- was fun, although the theme might not be my favorite.

item.name: Bora Bora
item.comment: This is a typical heavier Feld, not quite at the level of Trajan but it's almost there. There's goals stacked upon layers and layers of point-making diversions, all packed in a neat theme that is very colorful and bright but perhaps not as thematic as I would like. Overall, it is a solid brain-burning game but not my favorite of the Felds.

item.name: The Bottle Imp
item.comment: One of the best trick-taking games I've played. It gave me pleasant flashbacks to my days playing Hearts with the family. Only thing I didn't care for is the art and theme.

item.name: Box of Golf: A Classic Golf Board Game
item.comment: I bought this beauty for my dad for Father's Day. A great little game full of beautiful components -- so good, in fact, I have picked up another copy for myself! Best score: -12.

item.name: Broom Service
item.comment: I liked it better than Witch's Brew, because the board element is quite good. I'm not a super fan of the system, but it works well and I really can't complain. It's a good game and I would play again.

item.name: Bruges
item.comment: Another classic Feld with lots of different choices, with the catch that this is a 60-minute game. I like it ..

item.name: Buffy the Vampire Slayer: The Game
item.comment: The thematic tie-in into the game's mechanics is very cool (Oz and the werewolf). The game itself is quite basic fair at its core but some storytelling and imagination makes it pretty fun!

item.name: Burn in Hell
item.comment: As my friend Kirk said afterward: "Maybe we could get one of those clear binders to stick the cards in as I really enjoy the art and the bios but the game isn't anything to write home about."

item.name: But Wait, There's More!
item.comment: A fun variant to Snake Oil that my wife and I quite enjoy. The cards are written in ways that you just have no other choice but to use innuendo with, which makes me happy.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.comment: I'd like to try out the "advanced" version sometime, as the basic is fun but not much of a game. *Update* - played with Yukuza -- again, it was a fun time, but I really don't see much of a game here.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$: Yakuzas
item.comment: I really like the new weapons introduced -- but it still tries to complement a flawed system.

item.name: Cambria
item.comment: I find appeal in a game with my daughter's name. The game itself is so-so, a passable filler. I enjoy the dice-rolling, but the decisions are usually pretty small.

item.name: Camel Up
item.comment: There is a turtle game for kids that is quite similar to these mechanics, but this adds in a few extra hiccups. I do like that you're not necessarily given a horse/turtle/camel right from the beginning to bet on. But I don't think the game is varied enough from the games that I have like it to merit a purchase.

item.name: Campaign Manager 2008
item.comment: Amazing to have so much depth and fun in a deck of cards and some markers. Great theme and components.

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment: Good push-your-luck and I enjoy the stop sign board. It's clever and still holds up today.

item.name: Can't Stop: Rollin' Down the Highway
item.comment: Thanks Alan! It's not essential but it created a fun variant.

item.name: Captain Clueless: Lost in the Caribbean
item.comment: You can't say they're not creative. The kids still get a kick out of this one.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: This was my first tile-laying game, and from that point on tile-laying games became some of my favorites. I've also found that even youngsters can pick this game up and do quite well.

item.name: Carcassonne: Catapult
item.comment: For $5, worth every penny. The kids love it and when you're in a silly mood it creates a lot of fun.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 1 – Inns & Cathedrals
item.comment: A good add-in to Carcassonne, but I don't feel it's essential like I do with Traders & Builders.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 2 – Traders & Builders
item.comment: My favorite expansion to date. Speeds up the game and adds excitement - that little builder gives me much joy! And the giant castles ...!

item.name: Carcassonne: Hunters and Gatherers
item.comment: This is quickly becoming my favorite version of Carcassonne. There is something about the art and gameplay that I love.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Discovery
item.comment: A good implementation of Carcassonne. The only thing is, it's VERY thinky. If you like thinky and you want a beefed-up Carc, I think this would be a winner for you. For those of us that are used to the play-and-go Carcassonne style, it's a bit of a toss-up. A 6.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Mini Expansion
item.comment: Fun to have, nothing more to add.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Phantom
item.comment: A nice-looking small expansion that provides a neat wrinkle to the game. Nice to have the option to place twice.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Plague
item.comment: I actually enjoyed the fleas and rats more than I thought I would. It makes you focus on quicker scoring methods and takes away some of the advantage of drawing those cloisters. And of course, any kind of attacking in Carcassonne I usually find to be a blast.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Princess & the Dragon
item.comment: Non-essential but the Dragon is fun. I don't care for the Princess at all.

item.name: Carcassonne: The River
item.comment: To get this included for free in the base game is a steal. Great variant.

item.name: Cards Against Humanity
item.comment: It's Apples to Apples for a very specific crowd. The cards are mostly fun, some disgusting -- with the right folks and setting it can be hilarious.

item.name: Cards Against Humanity: 12 Days of Holiday Bullshit
Cards Against Humanity: The Bigger, Blacker Box
Cargo Noir
item.comment: This one falls into the light strategy family game genre that I usually enjoy the most. Typical beautiful Days of Wonder production. To start, I'm not completely sold on the game. It was enjoyable to play, but there isn't much for me to do while I wait for my turn. It's a simple set-collection, auction game that might just grow on me ...

item.name: Carson City
item.comment: Worker placement, which is great -- and the theme is there, too. The track is something that I'd have to get used to and probably like in the end. But something about the abstractness of laying out the buildings and connecting them didn't sit well with me.

item.name: Cartagena
item.comment: It's "Advanced Candyland". While perhaps a good filler or a good "step-up" for little ones, I didn't get much out of it. The production is not too nice, either. And the meeples look naughty.

item.name: A Castle for All Seasons
item.comment: Bland, dry, and most of all, it felt like it was playing itself. No useful decisions at all. Gorgeous board and art, and amazing overproduction. Too bad the game is not good.

item.name: Castle Keep
item.comment: A very fun game that is getting a lot of play with our family. Although with the attacking, sometimes it goes a bit long than what it should. But still, fun game.

item.name: Castle Panic
item.comment: Terrific game -- easy for everyone to understand, fun gameplay, Master Slayer variant makes it terrific. Mass market this baby!

item.name: Castle Panic: The Wizard's Tower
item.comment: Perhaps one of the few times I have rated an expansion higher than the base game. It makes Castle Panic grow up and that's a good thing.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment: What a surprise -- another great Feld game. This might be one of my top heavier games that I've played in the past few years. I like how the dice are used and I don't feel like there's a ton going on (like Trajan). It feels solid and I knew what I was doing quite well in just my first game. This could prove to be a 9 with more plays.

item.name: Castles of Mad King Ludwig
item.comment: Castles is certainly a great game and folks love it. I usually enjoy playing but sometimes I feel like its a bit too long for what it is. To me, the graphics and presentation could have been nicer, also. So I'll play, but I'm not enamored.

item.name: Catacombs
item.comment: It amazes me how genius the idea is, to take a flicking game and give it a purpose and a feeling of tension. Just INCREDIBLE fun! I absolutely love it. I think every play will be memorable. It's shot to the front of my son's favorite games. And it's really a whole different experience with adults! So fun! *Update* - would LOVE to get my hands on a Kickstarted 3rd edition.
item.conditiontext: 1st edition, player boards are laminated. Swapped out money cards with gems.

item.name: Catacombs
item.comment: Third edition is where it's at. The bigger boards are nice, the artwork I really enjoy and a vast improvement. One of the most creative games in history.

item.name: Catacombs: Dark Passageways
item.comment: Neat idea to give some more variety to the dungeons.

item.name: Catacombs: Cavern of Soloth
item.comment: Wow! So much terrific stuff in this expansion. This is what expansions should do -- really flesh out a game and give a ton more options. The designers really put their heart into this and came up with a TON of new ideas. Great stuff!

item.name: Catacombs: Cavern of Soloth
item.comment: Wow! So much terrific stuff in this expansion. This is what expansions should do -- really flesh out a game and give a ton more options. The designers really put their heart into this and came up with a TON of new ideas. Great stuff!

item.name: Catacombs: Crypt of Shaurath
item.comment: Unnecessary, but nice to have. Doesn't do anything mind blowing except add variety.

item.name: Catacombs: Horde of Vermin
item.comment: More Catacombs! Instant buy. Man, the small discs of the vermin and the poison cards are a great addition to the game. Perhaps it makes it even harder than Soloth did! I also love the upgrade cards and all the continued creativity. Vermin adds more fun to what I believe is the most creative game ever made. Thanks so much Oog, Greg, and Jim for the gift!

item.name: Catch Phrase!
item.comment: A 5 if you're not into it, but with a fun group it's very enjoyable. This is referring to the electronic version.

item.name: Cathedral
item.comment: Not much to it - an enjoyable puzzle game. My impression is the that the first player has a nice advantage. Very quick and a nice filler.

item.name: Cave Troll
item.comment: A lot of good meat and strategy packed into a short playtime. Excellent production. Really enjoying this one! Plays great with three, four seems a bit busy.

item.name: Caveman
item.comment: This is a good title for the family -- introduces some good gaming concepts and it's not hideous or anything to play. Rather quick as well. I would definitely recommend this for a new gaming family who hasn't been jaded by better games ...

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment: It's one of those "good game but not for me". In comparison to Agricola, well -- I'd choose Agricola because I know it better (thanks to the app). But to me, Caverna doesn't have the power to stay around long.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment: I think there are a lot of nostalgia votes for Caylus -- no doubt it is a solid game, and certainly once a GREAT game, but it has long since been surpassed by mechanics and theme in other games that I enjoy more. Keeping in mind, of course, that many of those games I enjoy more borrowed things from Caylus.

item.name: Champions of the Galaxy
item.comment: One of the most involving games I played in my youth. I had over 300 plays on this little card game growing up. It helped spawn my creativity and provided a wonderful outlet. Thanks for the memories, Tom!

item.name: Chang Cheng
item.comment: Excellent production and it really looks great on the table. A light euro that has a lot going for it. Looking forward to future plays and seeing if the rating can go up at all. I enjoyed the easy flow of the game and the scoring system.

item.name: Chaos in the Old World
item.comment: Just tremendous production and presentation in this game, and the different winning conditions for each god makes the game just appeal so strongly to me. Add in the wacky theme and the different strategies involved and I'm a HUGE fan! Quickly becoming one of my favorite games of all time. *Update* - almost five plays now and I am completely enthralled with every game. *update* -- I played Cthulhu Wars and now I realize that Chaos might be a bit cluttered and clunky. While this makes me sad and I had to adjust my rating after a recent play, I did love Cthulhu Wars ..
item.conditiontext: Player mats have been laminated. Green tokens have been replaced with plastic gems. Plano boxes.

item.name: Chaos in the Old World: The Horned Rat Expansion
item.comment: Wow, I didn't think it could be done. But the Horned Rat exceeded my expectation and allowed a five-player game in a game that I thought would never allow it. He worked and he seemed quite fun to play. My only gripe is that, while the new decks of cards given to the other players are fine, I think I like the old decks better. But hey, with the game now a 4-5 player game I can't argue! By the way, the models for the Rat and his friends are incredible ... Thank you STEPHEN for the great gift!

item.name: Château Roquefort
item.comment: There's some heft to this one, some good strategy for kids. But it's not the type of spacial awareness game that I enjoy playing, particularly. Beautiful game, though!

item.name: Chess
item.comment: Played chess many times in my youth, and really tried to figure it out. For quite a time I was the best player amongst my friends. But over the years I have lost interest in it as I have found so many other great games. I'm not much of an abstract lover in the first place. Still, a fun experience if your opponent does not take too long to play.

item.name: Chicago Express
item.comment: As stock games go, I didn't like it more than Airlines Europe. I didn't see what the excitement was all about. The travelling along the map amounts to what is basically a race and I didn't feel it meshed all that well. The guy that had one of each stock ran away with the game.

item.name: Chicken Cha Cha Cha
item.comment: Under the tree this year from Santa! The only memory game you need. One of the best kids games available today.

item.name: China
item.comment: There's something about this quick-playing euro that I love. Simple to learn and hard to master. Schacht is a true master at creating light rule strategy games.

item.name: Chrononauts
item.comment: Well, it's better than Fluxx. Unfortunately, there are a slew of flux-type mechanics in the game and I don't like that at all (as detailed on my Fluxx entry). I do like the theme, though, so it gets a point for that.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: I'd like to play with this 4 or 5 sometime. We played with 8 or 9 and it just didn't work for me like BGG said it would. Instead of Citadels, I'd rather play Mission Red Planet.

item.name: Cities
item.comment: A swell filler that we enjoyed. Clever ideas for scoring and placement. Ugly art.

item.name: Claustrophobia
item.comment: Fantastic two-player game. The depth of scenarios is limitless, and while the game feels like a combination of Descent and the Castle Ravenloft D&D series of board games, it doesn't have the monotony of the D&D games. Instant winner for me, can't wait to dive into the rest of the scenarios and the expansion. *Update* - it just seemed like more of the same as we went on. Disappointed.

item.name: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
item.comment: I really like Cleopatra not just for the amazing components (best I've seen in a game this size), but also for the different mechanics present and the way they are carried out. From the card shuffling to the mosaic placement, and of course the corruption, this is truly a memorable and enjoyable experience!

item.name: Click Clack Lumberjack
item.comment: Fun dexterity with a neat theme. One of the best pure dexterity games out there.

item.name: The Climbers
item.comment: An interesting abstract to be sure. The kids really enjoyed it, I could go either way. It just seems like the end is almost the same every time -- we all get to the point where we're all tied, and then someone squeaks it out.

item.name: Cloud 9
item.comment: Played several times as four-player with the family and it's gone over quite well! I think we all enjoy a bit of press-your-luck and this has it. Gorgeous components, too -- the best production I've seen from Out of the Box.

item.name: Clubs
item.comment: I couldn't get into it, but I wish the publisher well.

item.name: Clue
item.comment: A holiday favorite growing up. Now I find myself not really interested in deduction games as a whole.

item.name: Clue Jr.: The Case of the Missing Cake
item.comment: Better and quicker than regular Clue.

item.name: Cockroach Poker
item.comment: A game of set-collecting and bluffing -- definitely not what I was expecting. It's a good end-of-night experience and has some great, kooky drawings.

item.name: Coconuts
item.comment: A maddening fantastic game of dexterity. Highly recommended and works well with everyone. High quality of play and structure.

item.name: Code 777
item.comment: Oh man! What a clever deduction game. My wife loves it, and after my first play I'm convinced that I can do better than second place next time. I really enjoy games that have one page of rules and yet still create a good experience.

item.name: Codenames
item.comment: Worthy of the hype, Codenames is inventive and fun to play. If you're going to play a word-thinky game, it's worth your time to go with this one.

item.name: Color Stix
item.comment: Just one play, but enough to know it wasn't for me. There isn't much to the game and while it is very colorful, it just wasn't very fun. Also a bit concerned about the quality of the stickers on the wood, as it is not painted on and it could peel off with more plays.

item.name: Coloretto
item.comment: Good filler, quick to learn and teach. Not too sure about the art and presentation.

item.name: Colossal Arena
item.comment: I really like this game a lot -- quick, fun, thematic, and the wagering and "power backing" is very fun and inventive.

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment: Very clever, beautiful game. Wish it was not as long, but it's a lot of fun, especially for those that like future-planning.

item.name: Colt Express
item.comment: I am not a big programming game fan, but the bits in this one makes it special. The game itself is not amazing, but it does make a fun play with the presentation involved. Not needed to purchase but would play again.

item.name: Concordia
item.comment: Everyone seems to like this one a lot. I'm so-so on it. There's some clever things but not enough to make me want to like it. And when we're playing a dry euro with water printed on the board and shipping goods, the mechanics better be FREAKING AMAZING. I wasn't as impressed, unfortunately, with this one as much as others are.

item.name: Coney Island
item.comment: A typical Schacht. Always an enjoyable experience, an interesting spacial and give-take aspect to it. Coney Island is a solid game, but nothing spectacular.

item.name: Confusion: Espionage and Deception in the Cold War
item.comment: An amazingly-produced abstract, really top notch, but the game itself doesn't fascinate me at the same level of the production. I do think the design is one that should be in print, and fans of abstracts should go gaga over it. Solid.

item.name: Connections
item.comment: Unfortunately, there's not much here that makes me want to play it. It works, but it's blah.

item.name: Conquest of Pangea
item.comment: It was okay -- some neat ideas here and I'm thinking that people interested in the topic would really dig it. I'd play again no problem and enjoyed the experience.

item.name: Conquest of Planet Earth: The Space Alien Game
item.comment: CoPE is Flying Frog's second-best game behind the excellent Last Night on Earth. The formula works well and holds true in this effort, but make no mistake, the theme is what makes this truly shine. They have done a fantastic job incorporating this through the art and gameplay. A favorite of mine in the collection.

item.name: Container
item.comment: Neat little stock market game with terrific components. Looking forward to more plays, it was a lot of fun.

item.name: Core Worlds
item.comment: I didn't know what to expect from Core Worlds. I have grown tired of deckbuilders, and so I had an initial aversion to this one. But this doesn't feel as much like a deckbuilders as others do. There is a splash of Eminent Domain here, but just a tiny splash -- this is a lot more fun to play. There might be an issue or two at the end as it pertains to turn order and opportunity to get Core planets that you'd like to have, but beyond that, I enjoyed the play and would play again. Another thing to note is that I won the first time I played, which says a lot about the ability to learn the game as others had played a lot more times than I had.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment: I need more plays -- both times I played I was underwhelmed. I know there's a fun experience here! Just not sure how to obtain it yet. *Update* - I'm done trying to get this one. There's just way too many random cards and expansions with more random cards that can change the game at any time without anyone having any idea of it happening. Along with that you have the trouble of attacking someone that perhaps you didn't want to attack. I'm done with this one.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter: Cosmic Incursion
item.comment: I'd say that if you enjoy Cosmic, this is a no-brainer. The expansion cards do add a lot to the game, and a sixth player is a welcome addition. I don't care for the game personally, so this didn't save it for me. But as far as value for expansion, I think this is a GREAT expansion.

item.name: Coup
item.comment: Coup is in the realm of Resistance, but it adds in mystery player powers. I'm not sure yet. My kids enjoyed it very much, but I am getting less impressed with these types of games.
item.conditiontext: Great condition, played a couple times.

item.name: Coup: Rebellion G54
item.comment: The amount of roles and the ability to be interchangeable is fascinating. I give credit for a well-designed game, although I am not a huge fan of the Coup series. I can see why those would say this was the better of the two, though, because of the variety of cards.

item.name: Cranium
item.comment: Cranium is okay, and for the time that it emerged, perhaps it was one of the better party games out there. But there are just so many better games out there!

item.name: Cranium Hullabaloo
item.comment: Terrific game for kids learning shapes and words, and even then it's a lot of fun. One of the best kids games available.

item.name: Crokinole
item.comment: The high rating is truly justified -- the team game is fantastic and addictive. It may well be the best flicking game out there.

item.name: Crossfire
item.comment: Remember this? My finger still hurts.

item.name: Cthulhu Wars
item.comment: I have such a high interest in obtaining this game. Cthulhu Wars made me sit down and learn how to spell Cthulhu. It takes one of my favorite games ever, Chaos in the Old World, and flips it on its head by making it more approachable and less fiddly than CitOW. Cthulhu Wars has replaced CitOW for me, and I can't believe I said it, but I did. The components, of course, are insanely gorgeous. There's tons of expansions and it's a huge money sink. But I want the game badly, because it's great.

item.name: Cutthroat Caverns
item.comment: This is a ton of fun. With the right group and the right frame of mind, this could be the hit of the party. Some of the situations that come up are both hilarious and horrible at the same time, a great combination! Terrific system that deserves to be expanded and it has.

item.name: Cyclades
item.comment: My favorite hybrid game of 2009! Production is out of this world. Just love how different all those important prayers to the gods are, and how much they can change the game when done at the right time. With two players it's pretty good, with five it was a ton of fun. *Update* - Hades pushes Cyclades to a 10. Loved the heroes, new creatures, and Hades!

item.name: Cyclades: Hades
item.comment: One of the best expansions to a game I have played. Adds elements to make the game more fun (and varied) but doesn't add any kind of complexity or unwantedness. Fantastic!

item.name: D-Day Dice
item.comment: Fantastic co-operative game. It's come a long way from the PnP I used to play, evolved from a game that was a bit lifeless on printer sheets to glorious in real components, transformed from almost impossible to win to a very balanced and well-done ruleset. The expansions only add to the joy of the experience and doesn't bog down the game at all. And it successfully incorporated perhaps the only co-op I'd want to play competitively with Atlantikwall. GREAT GAME!

item.name: D-Day Dice: Atlantikwall
item.comment: Perhaps the only co-op that I would want to play competitively, thanks to how terrific this expansion is. Very well-developed ruleset and quite balanced. And best of all, it's FUN!

item.name: D-Day Dice: Badges
item.comment: I love the badges -- I consider them an integral part of the base game and I'm delighted to have them.

item.name: D-Day Dice: Distinguished Service Pack
item.comment: Not essential, but nice to have.

item.name: D-Day Dice: Free Trial Version
item.comment: Wow - great military-themed dice game. The support for the system is terrific. Recommended! Just know that it's hard as hell!

item.name: D-Day Dice: K-Pack
item.comment: I don't find these cards very functional, and I decided to only use two or three in the game. The Kickstarter themeing makes sense but doesn't quite fit the feel of the game as I would like. Still, a nice reward.

item.name: Damage Report
item.comment: I think the issue is that it just didn't seem to work. Complexity aside, it didn't work. Unbalanced or something. Even if it did work, there was something about the game that didn't flow to my liking. I'm a big fan of real-time games but this one didn't work for me.

item.name: Dark Minions
item.comment: It can feel a bit cube-pushing, and you really have to work to get the theme in your head. But the game works and can be fun. I will admit, I am letdown a bit at the final product. Also, ALWAYS play with the cards. It makes the game a lot more interesting and it's not difficult to pick up at all.

item.name: Dark Moon
item.comment: PnP copy. In a word, fantastic. I honestly felt like I was playing BSG -- the mechanics are quite different, but all the paranoia and desperation is still there. It's almost the freaking same feeling ... in two hours less time. Fantastic design! My favorite thing about it is that when you're rolling dice and really wanting to roll well, and you don't, and you HAVE to play -- the suspicion is overwhelming. It's just pure beauty and we had a great time with the first play. I hope I hope I hope this can see professional printing one day. *Update* - my hopes and dreams have been realized. I played the new copy of Dark Moon yesterday. It is good, and I enjoyed the play. I can't say whether or not how much staying power it has, but I will tell you that it knocks BSG out of the water. I expect to get plenty of plays out of the new version and congrats to the designer!

item.name: David & Goliath
item.comment: So far, I have found out that this is best 4 through 6 players -- which is AWESOME. *Update* - unfortunately, these type of games rarely get played here.

item.name: DC Comics Deck-Building Game
item.comment: I thought the mechanics were pretty good, and the game was enjoyable. I'm just not much of a comics guy, so all this stuff kind of flies by me.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
item.comment: The main thing I enjoy about Dead of Winter (after being one of the last gamers to actually get to play it) is that the repeated plays are going to be so varied. Love the amount of characters and options available, and the crossroads mechanic is a blast. Love that there "might" be a traitor each game. Fantastic work.

item.name: Deadlands: The Battle for Slaughter Gulch
item.comment: Deadlands is a game that I really want to like, but there's a few dangling mechanics that bother me. The theme and idea is there and the blind bidding actually works. But with the different and unbalanced ways to gain victory points, and the ever-changing endgame situation, it really falls flat in the end. Oh, note to game companies -- if the position of your miniature matters and it's built into the game's mechanics, make sure you create a wide enough base that the miniature can stand when you need it to stand.

item.name: Deep Sea Adventure
item.comment: I'd love to be persuaded otherwise, and maybe I need to play this again? I wasn't as impressed as others have been.

item.name: Defenders of the Realm
item.comment: Two through four, it's really quite fun all the way around. Getting into the theme makes it even more enjoyable. I really enjoy the main mechanics of the game, and although it seems like 120 minutes might be too long, it just feels like a perfect amount of time. Really enjoy watching the generals make their way across the field and trying to avoid all of those hideous losing conditions! The more I play it the more I'm enjoying it.

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: The Barbarian
item.comment: Definitely a great hero expansion, adds a lot of different angles to the group and a lot of fun to play.

item.name: Delve: The Dice Game
item.comment: An okay diversion for a few plays, but nothing that will hold my attention for very long.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment: I love it, and if the playtime was a bit shorter it would probably be my favorite game of all. Heroquest was my game when I was little, and now HQ grew up and here it is. My wife and I are in the middle of painting all the minis for this wonderful game. The campaign rules created with Road to Legend are awesome. One of my favorite games of all time. Just wish I could play it more.
item.conditiontext: Fully painted. Comes with laminated player mats found on BGG.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
item.comment: I was a huge proponent of Descent (first edition). Dungeon crawls speak to me, and Descent 1e has always stood out to be as the best dungeon crawler available. Personally, 2e has blown 1e away so far. The only flaw I had with 1e was the length. 2e fixes that, and the way it was fixed (that I initially feared) is a stroke of genius, and works, and is highly enjoyable. Being able to integrate 1e into the new edition is a huge plus. Everything is just lovely. I will own it forever.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition) – Alric Farrow Lieutenant Pack
Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition) – Eliza Farrow Lieutenant Pack
Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition) – Forgotten Souls
Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition) – Merick Farrow Lieutenant Pack
Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition) – Splig Lieutenant Pack
Descent: The Road to Legend
item.comment: Incredible depth and excitement added to the base game. The only problem is how rule-heavy it is, and how freaking long the campaign is to complete. It takes a lot of dedication. I really don't see myself getting it to the table much more, with all the other great games out there. Maybe one day. *Update* - Sold for $80.

item.name: Deus
item.comment: One of those games where I did the research and thought it was going to be great, and it just fell flat. I like that you can do so many things with the cards, but the problem is that unlike games where you can have several options that you want to do with multi-use cards, this one gave me lots of options but I just didn't want to do many of those actions. Many turns would go by that I just felt like I didn't do anything on, and that was the issue. Oh well.

item.name: Diamant
item.comment: Diamant is gorgeous and it adds to the fun of the game for me, so it gets a higher grade than Incan Gold. Although I will say that I think the treasures in Incan Gold make for a better game.

item.name: Dice Town
item.comment: This is just a barrel of fun. I really like it for what it is. And Matagot just does an excellent job with components.

item.name: Digit
item.comment: Solo puzzle game, great for traveling, but certainly replaced over the years by other puzzling efforts.

item.name: Dimension
item.comment: I love the idea of Dimension, and the components are just top notch beautiful. The game itself is just so quick and I'm not sure it's too difficult, either. Once the correct rules are used for bonus points it doesn't seem tough at all. I'm up in the air about this one, but as a puzzle fan, I'd like to keep it around for a while.

item.name: Diplomacy
item.comment: Wow - so after one play, I'm inclined to give this a 9. Due to player elimination, though, I have to hesitantly place it at 8 for now. But the experience is just so much fun, and tense as heck. For a game with such SIMPLE rules, it has amazing depth and tension. I loved our first play.
item.wishlistcomment: Probably the old Avalon Hill version with the blocks.

item.name: Discworld: Ankh-Morpork
item.comment: Oh dear -- randomness galore and hidden victory conditions. You could say it's not on my radar.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: You really need the right group for this one to fly. But when it flies it is quite fun, and a LOT better than Apples to Apples. *Update* Thank you JIM for the great present!*

item.name: Dixit Odyssey
item.comment: More of the same. Dixit is a solid party game, but I admit I do tire of it over time.

item.name: Dixit Quest
item.comment: Good expansion to a good game. "Dark Jasmine" will always be remembered.

item.name: Dominant Species
item.comment: One of the few heavier games that I've played that I've enjoyed. Of course, being worker placement and area control does influence my rating quite a bit. It's fun and very combative, but in the end, it's quite long (4 hours for three players) and there are some REALLY powerful cards in there. Solid game though. And oh yeah, I won my first play, so that helps too! But really, quite thematic for this type of game and although I was spent at the end, I had fun.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: Terrific deckbuilder that started it all. Very fun for 2-4 and once you get it down, you can get through a game in less than 30 minutes. I find Seaside and Intrigue to be terrific expansions as well.

item.name: Dominion: Intrigue
item.comment: I didn't think I would like Intrigue -- I was wrong. The cards are terrific.

item.name: Dominion: Seaside
item.comment: Seaside is where it's at. Things are still fun without being too complicated, and there's some great components involved here. I'm afraid that future expansions will start to get a bit more complicated after this, though.

item.name: Doodle Jump
item.comment: Surprisingly fun, but ends way too quick. But the gimmick works and I think they did a great job in retaining the feel.

item.name: Doom: The Boardgame
item.comment: Descent's predecessor is fun, but I'm more of a fantasy guy. The difference in mechanics, while small, still makes them quite different in gameplay. One of the biggest changes is that you can run out of ammunition in Doom, while in Descent you're fully stocked.

item.name: Down Under
item.comment: Light tile-laying game that didn't keep much interest. Played online at Yucata.de.

item.name: The Downfall of Pompeii
item.comment: A family favorite. Combines area control with tile-laying, two of my personal stalwarts! Also, this is a terrific entry-level strategy game for youngsters, but definitely enough there for adults who like the light-strategy genre. I rate it an 8 with two players, and a 7 for more players -- there is more control with 2.

item.name: Dr. Shark
item.comment: Disappointing effort here. The idea was very clever, but the components are a bit cheaper than they should have been, and the game is just jerky and doesn't flow very smooth. A good effort, but oh well.

item.name: Dragon Run
item.comment: Cute little game, but I can't imagine a lot of staying power. Still, a better game than a lot of others try to be.

item.name: Dragon Slayer
item.comment: Great art by my Chunky Fighter friend but the game itself, albeit pretty and some nicely-produced dice, isn't much. It can be labeled as a time-killer but really, there isn't a game out there that should be labeled as such.

item.name: Dragon's Gold
item.comment: This is a nasty, evil, cutthroat game of negotiation. The threats that are laid out around the table in this one can be catastrophic for acquaintances, though, so unless you are playing with some friends that "leave it all at the table" I suggest you skip this one! But for those that enjoy a great time, definitely look it up. I'm sure it's OOP these days, but it deserves to be in print no doubt. And I've found that it plays very well between 3-6. Just definitely play with the advanced rules!

item.name: Dragonheart
item.comment: I've played the game ~15 online, and after about 5 plays I would say it started getting dull. Add to that, the large amount of luck involved in hoping to draw the cards that you need, and it started to annoy me after a bit.

item.name: Drakon (third edition)
item.comment: Definitely recommend playing this with the variant of 'escaping with the treasure'. Finding eight coins and trying to get out is SO MUCH more satisfying than just collecting 10 coins and winning the game.

item.name: Dream Factory
item.comment: Neat little auction set-collecting game with a really fun theme. I like the components in my uberplay edition. There's just something missing that makes it stand out to me. Rather soulless, but I love the trophies.

item.name: Drum Roll
item.comment: I like Drum Roll. The art is fantastic and immersive, and I think it's a solid game. I'm still stunned that it takes 2-3 hours to play, though. The theme doesn't come through as well as I would have liked, but honestly, it's a solid, fun romp.

item.name: Duckling Dancin'
item.comment: I now consider this essential -- adds more players and actually helps to speed up the end of the game with the "poop" pieces. Expansion to Chicken Cha Cha Cha..

item.name: Duel in the Dark
item.comment: After playing this a few more times, I'm sad to say that it's really fallen out of favor with me. Components are a HUGE 10, and the theme is just great (so is the art). For me, the scoring mechanic in this one of making a move and having to check who is where, what hits what, etc x20 tied it down and made it blah. It just doesn't *feel* quite the way I'd like it to. But definitely a game that is unique and one that is worth playing some time.

item.name: Duel of the Giants: Eastern Front
item.comment: This one is a bit better than its cousin, Duel in the Dark, as the point scoring actually makes sense in this game. The ideas in this one are neat, but its abstract nature turn guesswork colored me a bit indifferent.

item.name: Dungeon Fighter
item.comment: Just so wacky, which is why I really like it! Party games need to be creative and have a distinct feel to them. This does both of those things quite well. Great, unique art also. Probably not a keeper but a fun pastime for now. *Update* - found out that it's truly a winner at 5+ players. As long as you don't mind a little downtime, which is fine because you are still involved rooting for your teammates. Unique party game.

item.name: Dungeon Fighter: Stormy Winds
item.comment: Some fun variants in here. We are big fans of the Fan Cannon!

item.name: Dungeon Lords
item.comment: With just one play, I'm not sure I'm qualified to talk about the merits of the game. But I didn't enjoy it -- I didn't feel the theme as much as I wanted, and I felt like I was just doing accounting opposed to having fun. Maybe I'll get a chance to play it again and change my mind, but it wasn't close to a winner for me.

item.name: Dungeon Raiders
item.comment: Cute little filler with a fun theme. Not much to it but that's the point! I really like games that can take a deck of cards and do some great stuff with it.

item.name: Dungeon Roll
item.comment: I actually like this one a lot more than Incan Gold and its ilk. It's a fun ride, really! Looking forward to playing it some more.
item.conditiontext: out of package, great condition. Treasure chest.

item.name: Dungeon Run
item.comment: Some great ideas here but unfortunately the ideas became mired in the muck of the endgame. I really like the mechanic for fighting enemies and I think there are some worthwhile things here, but it just didn't work for me. A shame.

item.name: Dungeon Twister
item.comment: An abstract in a very good disguise. Definitely one of the few abstracts I would consider owning, and I'm always up for a play of it.
item.conditiontext: Played twice, components bagged, and still in like new condition.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Attack Wing
item.comment: This was somewhat of a disappointment. It appears that the actual "advanced" game just added a lot of junk to the experience, and the "beginner" game didn't give a lot of substance. Great looking dragons and I'd love to see how the ground units work before I throw it out.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
item.comment: This is what I would call an experience game. It's not so much whether you win or lose as the fact that's it's quite fun to play and enjoy what happens. That said, there are still fun decisions to make, even though a card might come up that makes you do something you don't want to do. I love how the scenarios can be replayed as well, with no concerns of repeating anything. It's a genius system, no doubt, and will certainly be expanded and enjoyed for many years to come. *Update* - 10 plays in and I'm finding this system to be a bit uninspired. I'm not sure whether it's the blandness of the graphic design or whether the mechanics don't feel fresh anymore, but something has definitely been lost here.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game
item.comment: We've enjoyed Drizzt so far. Much like Ravenloft, the system works well and we enjoy co-ops, though I have nothing telling me we'll be holding on to Drizzt any more than we held on to Ravenloft. But in the end, I think Drizzt will be seen as the best in the series (note, I have yet to play Ashardalon).

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Board Game
item.comment: It's more of the same ... I do like this better than the original and I LOVE the Dragon mini. But it just seems like the three games blend all into one after a while, and I'm just not as keen on the system as I'd like to be.

item.name: Duplik
item.comment: Another drawing party game, this pales in comparison to several others that I've played. It's fun, but just not close to Telestrations and others.

item.name: Dweebies
item.comment: Tiny bit of strategy here, enough to keep the adults interested. Kids absolutely love the art and the game. A definite winner and one of the top kids games.

item.name: Eaten by Zombies!
item.comment: Very clever deckbuilder that clogs up your hand with zombies -- unfortunately for the good guys that's how you win! The art is rather gory but the gameplay is very creative and solid.

item.name: Edo
item.comment: Solid. I didn't see much theme, but the mechanic was good. Good enough to make it a great game? I don't think that is the case, but I would still play and enjoy it.

item.name: Egizia
item.comment: Wow! This might be my favorite euro of 2009. It reminds me of a more-involved Stone Age, which is a terrific thing. I just like how everything seems very complicated to start, but how it just flows very easily once you start in. I was very competitive in my first game which tells me it does well in that area. Great game.

item.name: Eight-Minute Empire: Legends
item.comment: I couldn't get into this. Even as a filler, it's just not my style of game. It feigns conflict and interaction, but really I just don't feel like there is any. GREAT artwork.

item.name: Elder Sign
item.comment: So far I'm just not sure. There are things that I like, and then there's those "Fantasy Flight" issues such as imbalance, chaos, and rule complexity. I like a lot of things here, though, and definitely willing to keep playing.

item.name: Elfenland
item.comment: This is as Alan Moon as it comes. Playing this in 2012 felt quite silly after enjoying a lot of his other designs. And I definitely saw the inspiration from those others as well in Elfenland. A solid route-building game and some enjoyment certainly to be had.

item.name: Elk Fest
item.comment: Honestly? There's not much here. Cute filler, I guess? Would get a better score if it was four players.

item.name: Elysium
item.comment: It seemed like it was trying to be a complicated 7 Wonders. I wasn't too high on it and don't need to play again.

item.name: Eminent Domain
item.comment: I think ED is a good game. It feels like the designer has meshed together Race for the Galaxy, Glory to Rome, and Dominion to create it. It's really stunning how the game has taken major parts of those three games to create this and that the game works well enough! So while it is not an original idea to be sure, it works fine and I thought it was okay. But is it better than any of those games? No, I don't think so. Maybe better than GtR, but not the others.

item.name: Emu Ranchers
item.comment: It's a solid game with some neat dual-card abilities. But let's be honest and say it's a variant of Lost Cities. A lot of times it allows me to do something I wish I could do in Lost Cities, but does that mean we're dumbing down my decisions or giving me more? Interesting. And I wish there were more cards in the deck, the game ends very quickly. I wish them the best.

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment: One of my favorite euros of 2009. Enough tactics and decisions to make a great game, and yet, not hard enough to learn that you can't win the first time you play. Excellent!

item.name: Enigma
item.comment: It's nice, but it doesn't stand out from the rest of the great puzzle games worth keeping.

item.name: Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards: Duel at Mt. Skullzfyre
item.comment: This game is ALL about the artwork and the silliness. The mechanics themselves are quite random and poor. So I imagine this would be good for a few laughs, and then set aside.

item.name: Eruption
item.comment: Fun, quick screw-you game that plays smooth and sound. While I have a hard time understanding how straw blocks lava, and im conscious of the fact that you need to have a tough skin, its an excellent end of the night exercise. Just not sure if it is too combative for families or not

item.name: Escape: Illusions
item.comment: A nice, essential expansion that really broadens your experience. Expansions are important for this game, and there's plenty of room for creativity here. Happy with this one and can't wait for more.

item.name: Escape: Quest
item.comment: I think Quest jumped the shark just a bit. A small bit. I like it, but if this is where the game ends I'm happy.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
item.comment: Quickly becoming one of my favorite titles of 2012 along with being a personal favorite. I already love real-time games, and this takes real-time to a very fun level rolling dice. The quick playtime allows it to come out often and the party atmosphere always makes it a good time. Haven't even explored all the expansions yet and I know that there is lots of room for more. Can't wait!

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple – Doomed
item.comment: More fun.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple – The Pit
item.comment: Fun tile to add. Very clever and thematic.

item.name: Evolution
item.comment: Two plays on a built-it-ourselves copy. Some clever ideas here. Not sure if it is my card bias I have or what, but I didn't flip over it. But I can see the merits here! Some great ideas and it will do well.

item.name: Excape
item.comment: Very light, luck-based filler game with a neat party-type atmosphere. A kick to play! Great option for six players.

item.name: Expedition: Northwest Passage
item.comment: Such a beautiful game. I'm happy with this purchase so far, but there is something that makes me wonder if future plays will be so fun. For now, enjoying it very much and I love how different a feel it has than everything else out there. I look forward to more Expedition games, by the way ...

item.name: Faces
item.comment: Not enough faces included for this one to be a keeper. It did play well with 6 players, though.

item.name: Fairy Tale
item.comment: Ingenious drafting mechanic makes this one a winner for me. I think we played the game 8 times in 30 minutes.

item.name: Fallen
item.comment: From the first play, you can tell that this was a unique idea and implementation. Very clever mechanics. I enjoyed the back and forth battle feeling. So curious what more could be done with the system.

item.name: Fast Flowing Forest Fellers
item.comment: Great production as expected from 2F. Light, fun racing game with a lot of different tracks in the box. Great fun for all ages. I'm just not much of a race fan.

item.name: Fast Lane
item.comment: This is NOT Fast Lane/Wild Horses ... this is an AMAZINGLY-made version that features my family, put together by Hanibal and Megan for me. We love it! A great present, and a really fun game.

item.name: Fearsome Floors
item.comment: Another excellent and fun design from 2F. Production values are outstanding (how many games allow you to assemble your own monster?) Fun game, terrific theme.

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
item.comment: Neat little bidding press-your-luck game -- great present from David, thanks! Jasmine loves the art. And of course, I am the best at press-your-luck so I'm ecstatic! *sarcasm* But it really is a fun little game and a great filler.

item.name: Filipino Fruit Market
item.comment: Clever trick-taking game with some really neat ideas. That is in reference to Tindahan, one of the two games included.

item.name: Finca
item.comment: Second play was very enjoyable. I'm impressed how well the game covers two players. Really liking the flow of the game after a few plays. It looks like two players is best for this one, too. Four players is just too many for the system.

item.name: Finito!
item.comment: There's some fun here and the idea is a good one. But ultimately, you're playing a numbers game. It's a good numbers game, but there's not much to it.

item.name: Fireball Island
item.comment: My favorite game as a kid is now my son's favorite game!

item.name: Firefly: The Game
