item.comment: This is a game that you don't necessarily need to know the theme to play, but might be essential in order to enjoy it. The mechanics are mostly pick up and deliver, which fits the theme well -- but without the theme, it would seem quite dry. I like that there are some open-endedness with the jobs, though, although the traveling is a bit much at times. Even after all that, the theme is fun, and I would much rather play it over Merchant of Venus.

item.name: Firenze
item.comment: Light eurogame that's easy to learn. The decisions come in with building towers and trying to beat other players on building them higher. The theme is weak but the game is enjoyable.

item.name: FITS
item.comment: I'm getting better at this! I really am! Terrific game that will always be on my shelf. Expansions really flesh the game out and keep it fresh.

item.name: FITS Expansion #1: MOTS – More Of The Same
item.comment: It's more of the same ... good stuff.

item.name: FITS Expansion #3: BOTS – Big Obnoxious Terrible Spaces
item.comment: It's horrible - and a lot of fun! :) Believe it or not, you can get some pretty great scores out of these things, as evil as they are.

item.name: FITS Official Expansion
item.comment: I think it's my favorite expansion to FITS so far. Not sure why it's rated so low, and don't care -- because I like it!

item.name: Five Tribes
item.comment: Fantastic return to relevance for Days of Wonder. The art and gameplay are both phenomenal. My pick for best game of 2014 so far.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment: Quickly moving up the ladder (haha) of my top games of all time. Would not be surprised to see this reach 10 someday. Has a lot of things incorporated that I love (co-op, quick actions/playtime), theme)

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue – Extreme Danger
item.comment: So this is probably my least favorite expansion, because I think between you and me, I believe this is when Flash Point jumped the shark. I really dug the two-story building and I liked the variety and creativity of some of the other boards from other sets. Extreme Danger seemed to add a bit too much to the game for my taste. The garage was more frustrating than fun to me, and the laboratory felt like it was pushing the system farther than it should be pushed. In addition, I don't really think I would want to add the attic or basement to any map. Three floors really stretches the boundary of what this system can do. Regardless, the game is fantastic.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue – Urban Structures
item.comment: Does what you would want for an expansion. Love the two new boards, very challenging, creative, and fun. Really enjoying the new role as well. If you enjoy the original, this is a must-have.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue – Veteran and Rescue Dog
item.comment: The dog is actually a blast to play with.

item.name: Fluffy Bunny Tea Party
item.comment: Wowsers! Honestly, I played this with the best possible group that could ever play it. Fluffy Bunny Tea Party with Atticus is a dream come true. And we had fun impersonating high-society bunnies with British accents. So it was a good, fun experience -- for the first time. I can't imagine that this could continue to be amazing, because the game itself sucked. But I gave it a 5 for the fun first time.

item.name: Fluxx
item.comment: I just don't see the appeal.

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: Easy to learn and teach, great filler. It's an auction game, and you're not sure exactly how much money to commit. It's fun, though, and quick. And I love the art. Thanks Mike for the gift!

item.name: Forbidden Desert
item.comment: This is perhaps better than Forbidden Island. They're not really all that similar besides the time mechanic, and I love the new roles and theme. Absolute winner from Leacock. Again.

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment: Terrific game all the way around, so easy to teach and play with all sorts of different folks - another home run by Mr. Leacock.

item.name: Formula D
item.comment: Argh! I want to love this but I can't quite get there. I feel like the decisions are kind of made for me every turn. Excellent production and detail, though, make me keep hoping that it "turns the corner" for me.

item.name: Formula E
item.comment: Really good racing game, some excellent ideas here. I'd love to play this with 5-6 players and see how it plays also. The cardplay is very clever involving obstacles that any player can move. The theme rocks!

item.name: Formula Motor Racing
item.comment: This strikes me as a good way to kill some time with a big group of folks. The version with the actual cars in it makes it a lot more fun. Another great 6-player filler.

item.name: Fortune and Glory: The Cliffhanger Game
item.comment: Fortune and Glory, by itself, is a passable game. I'd give it a 6, probably, if I hadn't played other Flying Frog titles. And there's the rub -- I love Last Night on Earth and it has a solid spot in my heart. But FF has made four games since then -- Invasion from Outer Space (a LNoE clone), A Touch of Evil (a somewhat-creative game that I didn't enjoy), Conquest of Planet Earth (would love to play this co-op), and now this. Well, five games later, and I'm still seeing 90% of this game having LNoE mechanics. I mean, come on. It makes for a repetitive, almost dull experience to keep having the same things in their games. And I see what they were trying to do here, and it's a great effort, it is. But man, the collapsing of temples and cliffhangers and everything -- I didn't like ANY of it. The rest is just stuff I've seen before. I haven't played CoPE yet, but I'm willing to bet that some of the same mechanics are in that one too. FF better step it up with the next game. Come on guys, you have a great company, but FanG was a step back.

item.name: Frag
item.comment: Yikes - I didn't enjoy it.

item.name: Fresco
item.comment: Certainly not a 45-min game, our first game with four players was two hours. Lends itself to a lot of AP. That said, wonderful theme and production. I'm not in love with it, but I did enjoy the play. *Update* - second play in the books and I'm still quite frustrated with it. I want to like it but I don't, and that's not going to change at this point. There's something that bugs me about the design and that just can't be adjusted to.

item.name: Friday
item.comment: Good for a couple plays. I can't see anyone wanting to hang onto this, though -- the depth of play is variable but not intoxicatingly so. The art is cute and the mechanics work, no doubt -- it's a good solo experience.

item.name: Friday the 13th
item.comment: It has to be 4 players and up, but when that is the condition, it's a lot of fun as a nice light filler. The main problem is the game length and repetitiveness.

item.name: Frog Juice
item.comment: Thanks, Kirk, for Cambria's birthday present. Frog Juice is a quick filler with a good amount of luck and a chance to make some neat combos. Fun game.

item.name: Froggy Boogie
item.comment: This is an immediate favorite with both daughter and son!

item.name: Funny Friends
item.comment: Honestly, there's a good game here hidden beneath the gimmick. I enjoyed it beyond the theme. I think it's a keeper on the whole.

item.name: Galaxy Defenders
item.comment: I found both this one and Robinson Crusoe around the same time and I'm feeling quite fortunate these days. This game works. The movement mechanics are, yes, borrowed but in no way does it feel forced. It works GREAT with the game and they did a fantastic job with this. The character powers and upgrades are a blast and the scenarios have been well thought-out so far. Painting the figures and keeping this one for a long time.
item.conditiontext: Almost completely painted. Played several times. Great condition.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: The more I play, the more I seem to get frustrated. I think it's a kick of a game, and I want to play it, but for some reason I'm stuck in the middle of whether I'm enjoying it! A true enigma for me.

item.name: The Game of Authors
item.comment: For a game that's essentially Go Fish, it was tolerable and contained a good amount of trivia.

item.name: A Game of Thrones (first edition)
item.comment: The theme made this playable for me, but halfway through I felt like I wanted out. If you're looking for this type of experience, I'd say to just play Diplomacy. There's too many clunky mechanics for me in this, things that just seem to draw out the game. And releasing the first edition without those fixes (the ports) is just inexcusable. The theme really carried me through and made it okay.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: A Clash of Kings Expansion
item.comment: It would seem to me that if you're into the base game, getting this expansion is a must-purchase.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: A Storm of Swords Expansion
item.comment: I liked the two leader tokens, they were fun to use.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game
item.comment: Absolutely BEAUTIFUL art and components. Most likely the most gorgeous card game I've seen to date. The game itself is okay. I felt like it's just saturated with stages and it's just so complicated and involved. You really need to know exactly what other cards people have and what they do, so perhaps after a number of plays I could see enjoying the game more, but with the length of play with four players I'm not sure I'm going to be playing it that much. Still, for fans of card combat games, it's excellent.

item.name: Game of Thrones: The Card Game
item.comment: These kind of card games don't tend to grab me. I see the game in there but the amount of luck and decisions don't cause me to see the joy in the system. The theme is what got me to play, for sure.

item.name: Gauntlet of Fools
item.comment: The game itself is fine, although VERY short. If the game consisted of simply the second round, I'd think it would be fair or so. The first round is a auction-type round, and it's just downright silly and might last longer than the actual gameplay. Donald X, not sure this is a good one.

item.name: Gemblo
item.comment: A nice variant to Blokus, and a beautiful presentation, but certainly not different enough to warrant having both in my collection.

item.name: Genesis
item.comment: Genesis takes a stab at two things I haven't seen done well in games -- Christian themes and tattoo-style art. It did a good job with both, but not enough to keep around. The simplistic mechanics isn't good enough these days, and doesn't stack up against competitors like Tokaido.

item.name: Get Bit!
item.comment: I had my doubts about this one and was able to play it before the Kickstarter campaign ended. Well I jumped on to back it after the play. The component quality is great and it really adds to the flavor of the game. I wasn't sure that there would be enough game here but it's simple and strategic enough to be a great filler for all ages.

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment: I really like co-op games, and this is a seriously awesome one. Great components, art, and theme -- and what a killer challenge! At this point I would have to say that Ghost Stories is reaching the level of Pandemic for me, and perhaps is poised to overtake it. *Update* - 10 plays through and I've increased the rating from 9 to 10. I LOVE Ghost Stories. And the expansion is incredible too.

item.name: Ghost Stories: White Moon
item.comment: One of the best expansions I've played. It's a must-have for me, as it cranks up the fun and incorporates a good amount of new things, but the complexity level stays the same. It just feels like a fresh way to play the game and doesn't inhibit the experience in any way, just adds to it. I love Su-Leng and the balance she gives to all the naughtiness going down. Great expansion! Thanks Tony for the great gift!

item.name: Ghosts!
item.comment: Well, this was fun when I was a kid. But by today's standards it really does not hold up for me at all. Good idea, but where is the strategy here?

item.name: Ginkgopolis
item.comment: A solid euro game. No need to purchase. Solid game.

item.name: Glen More
item.comment: Uh-oh. I thought I would like this game. I did not. Glen More is so abstract and so tedious I wanted to quit before the end. Perhaps I'm being too harsh with that sentence but by the time the end did come I got rather upset with the scoring system. It's just not for me, I guess.

item.name: Gloria Mundi
item.comment: I went in not expecting much and came out with a pretty positive impression on a very fun game. It's a race game at its heart, but to win the race you have to not only do a smart job at creating your own resources and buildings but you have to screw over your opponent as well. Very fun!

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment: This was actually a cool game, I'm just finding that these types are not really my type.

item.name: Gnome Crystals
item.comment: Small-press production, but still a nice presentation. The game itself is a clever usage of dice.

item.name: Going to Jerusalem
item.comment: Cool pieces! The game was standard junk for the time period.

item.name: Going, Going, GONE!
item.comment: More fun than it should be. This has the makings of a winner.

item.name: The Golden City
item.comment: A very good, easy-to-play Schacht euro. I'm very pleased with it and will always be interested in playing. I continue to enjoy Mr. Schacht's games, as I love the quick decisions involved and the engaging gameplay. Also, The Golden City has auctions, so that's good!

item.name: Gone Fishing!
item.comment: Not much to it, the concept works and is fine, but there is nothing engaging enough that I want to go back and play it again.

item.name: The Good, the Bad, and the Munchkin
item.comment: No. See my comments on Munchkin Booty.

item.name: GOSU
item.comment: Played online several times -- a very nicely done game of war using cards and combos. While I find it a good game with some fun strategy, it's not as incredibly fun as I had hoped. Still, I am down for a play anytime, and the art and theme is great.

item.name: El Grande
item.comment: Waiting for another play to truly comment on how great I think this game is.

item.name: The Great Fire of London 1666
item.comment: Played with three and five so far. Enjoyable plays -- theme is perfectly connected and the board and components are lovely. A different feel to this one which makes it an absolute keeper.

item.name: Guesstures
item.comment: It was fun watching my kids being used as props for this!

item.name: Gulo Gulo
item.comment: My 3-year-old legit beat me -- now this is a family game! The Zoch series is one of the best available for kids today.

item.name: Hab & Gut
item.comment: A fun stock market game that worked a lot better than I thought it might.

item.name: Haggis
item.comment: Very clever climbing game, its fun to play something like tichu with 3-4.

item.name: Hamsterrolle
item.comment: Cool dexterity action in a hamster wheel. What a genius to think this one up.

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment: Excellent co-op game of deduction and betrayal! Well, not betrayal, but it sounded fun to say. Seriously, what a great card game this is. Really enjoyed the two plays so far. Bauza is becoming one of my favorites.

item.name: Hanabi & Ikebana
item.comment: Excellent co-op game of deduction and betrayal! Well, not betrayal, but it sounded fun to say. Seriously, what a great card game this is. Really enjoyed the two plays so far. Bauza is becoming one of my favorites.

item.name: The Hanging Gardens
item.comment: It took a few plays, but I'm starting to get it. Solid game that really just using a card overlay mechanic, and it's quite superb when you look at it that way.

item.name: Hansa Teutonica
item.comment: Definitely a game that requires me to play once just to understand. After the first play, you can really get a handle on the different strategies. One of those games that I acknowledge is a good game, but not one that I enjoy. *Update* - second play was better than the first. Still not a fan of the mechanics and lack of theme, but a good game. It's just not FUN.

item.name: Hansa Teutonica: East Expansion
item.comment: I think this is a better board than the original one. I had more fun on it (and scored better) than on the original, too.

item.name: Harry Potter: Diagon Alley Board Game
item.comment: Not terrible at all - there is roll-and-move here, but there's at least some strategy to it through cardplay. The only drawback is the sheer luck when drawing cards. Still good fun to play with the boy.

item.name: Harry's Grand Slam Baseball Game
item.comment: A little monotonous and not much there. It's a good "beer & pretzels" game but really, I have so many. The theme is 10+ but I wish the game had some more decisions to it.

item.name: Hawaii
item.comment: The first game that I've seen try to duplicate the Vikings island-building mechanic, and it does it in a fun way when you jumble it with all of the other things going on. The theme is a disconnect, but it's still fun to play with tikis and such. Worker placement is a winning mechanic for me, too, so I liked it very much.

item.name: HeroQuest
item.comment: My first intro to the miniature world, and it was good. I still enjoy the game a ton and we've adapted plenty of house rules along the way. And now my son and I have started through the quests again!

item.name: HeroQuest: Barbarian Quest Pack
item.comment: This was not playtested. The minis are gorgeous, I love everything about it, except the way it plays. Tons of houseruling would be needed to give the heroes any kind of a chance. The monsters are just WAY too powerful and plentiful.

item.name: HeroQuest: Elf Quest Pack
item.comment: See comments on the Barbarian expansion.

item.name: HeroQuest: Kellar's Keep
item.comment: A little monotonous at times but a good first expansion for the series.

item.name: HeroQuest: Return of the Witch Lord
item.comment: This is more like it! Excellent expansion, my favorite so far.

item.name: Heroscape Marvel: The Conflict Begins
item.comment: Not as good as I had hoped -- does not present the system in its best light, I feel. But hell if it's going anywhere, son loves it!

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
item.comment: This made a serious impression in my life and turned me back to gaming as a pastime. At the start of 2010 I decided to sell most of my collection to help finance my love of board games, but I couldn't part with all of it. A great system for new players to jump into the hobby with, and also very friendly to the kids.

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Swarm of the Marro
item.comment: I really, really like this set, and have introduced a lot of new players with it.

item.name: Hex Hex
item.comment: Okay for a quick filler here and there.

item.name: Hey, That's My Fish!
item.comment: The Deluxe version. Again, much like Taluva, it's all about the fact that this is fun to look at that makes it more than just an abstract. This could have been put together with some grains of rice and tokens, if you think about it. The penguins and fish really make it.

item.name: High Bohn Plus
item.comment: Terrible ruleset and rather unnecessary additions make this a useless expansion.

item.name: High Society
item.comment: An interesting filler, nothing special really ...

item.name: Himalaya
item.comment: Robo Rally meets pick up and deliver game. It plays very well and runs smooth, but there's such a huge luck element to where things end up that it makes it a bit hard to plan. It also gives you that terrible feeling of making a great plan for a turn and then realizing right in the middle that you can't change it so your turn is pretty much wasted. But, if you feel like a game with some chaos, it's a great fun option!

item.name: Hive
item.comment: Interesting abstract with gorgeous components. Not sure the game would be as good without the components, but there are some clever ideas here for the abstract fans. Definitely takes a few plays to get your head around it, but a very good abstract that I would recommend.

item.name: Hive: The Ladybug
item.comment: The idea of the Ladybug is fine but I'm not sure it adds more to the game or not.

item.name: Hive: The Mosquito
item.comment: Love the Mosquito, being able to copy others abilities makes for a great piece.

item.name: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey
item.comment: I think it's good for a couple plays, but a couple things annoy me. First, my son didn't care for it too much. He felt like it was quite punishing, and since you are relying a lot on what you roll, this can be true. Second, I really don't like that the game was obviously built with the intention that we buy all the expansions to make it a complete game. Right in the rules, it says to keep playing on the expansion board that to my knowledge is not even out yet. The game is okay, but this is not a keeper for me.

item.name: Hoity Toity
item.comment: Another older game that I'm sure was amazing for its time. Now the mechanics have been used in greater fashion IMO and the theme is yuck.

item.name: Homesteaders
item.comment: I had a great first impression of Homesteaders. The mechanics were tight and very well done, and I prefer this over many of the bidding games I've played. I played with the first edition, with the knowledge that second edition is much nicer. Would gladly play again.

item.name: Hop Hop Hooray!
item.comment: Big time sleeper hit with the kids! Thanks Lana for the present! I have to admit, I rather like this one too ...

item.name: Hornet
item.comment: Hornet has some incredible components and a terrific theme going for it. After just one play, it is tough to talk about the mechanics and what I liked or didn't like, but I found the game enjoyable and there's a certain charm about it. Looking forward to another play.

item.name: Hotel Tycoon
item.comment: You know, for an older roll-and-move game, I enjoyed this. Much better than Monopoly, because there are more choices involved and the game has a solid ending time to it (it can't go on and on). Beautiful components and a fun board to look at. With some touching-up, this could be put back in print and do very well.

item.name: Hula Hippos
item.comment: Thanks for the gift, Lana! The kids love this simple filler and I enjoy it too. :) Good flicking fun.

item.name: I Hate Zombies
item.comment: RPS with some player powers. It's okay and really something I would play with just family and kids. The kids thought it was okay.

item.name: I Hate Zombies: We Hate Zombies Too
I Spy Eagle Eye
item.comment: It's very simplistic in terms of gameplay -- find an item on a picture -- but I guess it held the kids' attention for a few minutes.

item.name: Illuminati
item.comment: What can I say. Typical Steve Jackson game. Better than Munchkin! Not into the theme and the gameplay was quite bland. There also was several sightings of possible broken gameplay and cards.

item.name: In the Year of the Dragon
item.comment: One of the toughest games I've played in terms of not having bad things happen to you. You have to accept that some of your strategies are not going to work out. That said, an enjoyable idea and a lot of (stressful) fun.

item.name: Inca Empire
item.comment: A good game with solid mechanics and fun. Looks a lot harder to play and learn than it actually is. Great art and colors. Would like to play anytime!

item.name: Incan Gold
item.comment: So easy to play and can hold so many people. I am thinking it is at its best with a lot of folks. Unfortunately, I am horrible at push-your-luck games! I just can't stop!

item.name: Indigo
item.comment: Knizia took Tsuro and gave it more of a meaning. Much more interesting to have several things to be vested in obtaining than to keep just one piece alive. I like the game and I think it should do well. Good family time playing, my 7-year-old enjoyed it.

item.name: Innovation
item.comment: Innovation is certainly a creative game. I really like the different things you can do with your cards. It does help to have a strong knowledge of all the cards and what they can do, though. I also can see why it has its detractors -- it's not easy to have things taken away just because someone happened to draw a certain card. Poor Sam had to suffer through two games of getting owned and poor card draws. If I had that kind of game I might look differently on it, but for now, I'd certainly play it again and enjoyed the first two plays enough.

item.name: Intrigue
item.comment: Not a terrific first play, but fun enough to warrant another try. Trying to determine if you can really make many alliances in this game. If you do, no doubt they will fall apart 10 minutes later.

item.name: La Isla
item.comment: I am finding that I tend to dislike the shorter Felds. The man has a weakness.

item.name: Isla Dorada
item.comment: Well, the production quality is wonderful, and that is my saving grace with this one. The game is actually quite fun and I would play again, but I wasn't too hot on all the random cards that came out and the rest of the luck involved. I mean, I like luck, but yikes! A little too much for me. Still fun, though, we still love ya Bruno.

item.name: The Isle of Doctor Necreaux
item.comment: A fun little card game to pass the time. Difficult, but very clever and replayability is seemingly endless. Solo record 2-6. Unfortunately, I've found that the enormous swings of luck can make this a bit annoying at times, and the two-player games that we played of this were just okay.

item.name: Istanbul
item.comment: This was a good game, but it was nothing to write home about. I wouldn't call it soulless by any means. I'm not sure there's a lot that would pull me back to it, though.

item.name: It Happens..
item.comment: Terrific dice filler. Great art. I like that there's just enough strategy to have a game but not too much to exclude others. Would work for a variety of settings. Too bad the name is such a poor choice. We call it the "anteater game". Good stuff Feld! Thanks for the present David!

item.name: JAB: Realtime Boxing
item.comment: Clever realtime game, that gives quite an edge to an opponent who has played before. Mixes a whole mess of realtime mechanics in one. I'd liken it more to Speed, because quickness of hand and eye trumps all. Not a bad little title.

item.name: Jaipur
item.comment: Our favorite new two-player game to come along in quite a while! Excellent mechanics and value for your $.

item.name: Jamaica
item.comment: Light, fun racing with a few decisions splotched in here and there. Absolutely gorgeous production, some of the best there is. Terrific family racing game! Thanks Dice Tower secret santa!

item.name: Jamaica: Extra Treasures
item.comment: Happy to have these three cards, but there's not much to it.

item.name: Jasper and Zot
item.comment: Love the theme and artwork. It plays out like a video game, and sure is a nice solo experience.

item.name: Junta: Viva el Presidente!
item.comment: I always enjoy a good negotiation game! This one has dice and attacking in it, too, and even comes with a pair of sunglasses in the box (!) Would love to play again. *Update* - now that I have, it just seems that the rules aren't solid enough to provide a fantastic experience every time. The last time we played, while fun, was a bit "empty". I'd play it again, but it's off the wishlist.

item.name: Ka-Boom
item.comment: Fun ideas and components - it's a good time if you don't take it too seriously. And that's hard to do when people are flinging blocks at you while you're trying to build a structure. :)

item.name: Ka-Ching!
item.comment: Eh. The game works but I'm not convinced it's any fun.

item.name: Keltis
item.comment: Lost Cities for four players works just fine, and the board and colors are truly gorgeous. With two, I wouldn't recommend it -- to me, it is strictly for 3-4 players. A nice, quick filler-type.

item.name: Kemet
item.comment: My first play I had some issues with the general layout of the board and the mechanics. Maybe we played something wrong, but it seemed like you would build up your forces, take a shot at attacking, and then regroup and do it again. Odd point disbursement. Want to love it as I love Cyclades, but I didn't see any of the attraction of that game.

item.name: Key Largo
item.comment: Fun mechanics with a great diving-for-treasure theme. Good fun with just three players, looking forward to trying with more. Clever, fun game! Excellent for youth to introduce some mechanics to them young, as well.

item.name: Keyflower
item.comment: A solid eurogame, much like the designer's Keythedral. Nothing entirely special here, but there's nothing bad to speak of, either. A well-done euro.

item.name: Keythedral
item.comment: Neat little euro with some clever mechanics that I'm sure were borrowed from some and copied by others. What stands out to me was that I had a good time playing, and the presentation is spectacular. Every tile and chip in the game had a different piece of artwork on it -- that is very impressive.

item.name: Khet: The Laser Game
item.comment: A totally neat abstract, but it's pretty hardcore in the thinking department for me. Great ideas and nice implementation/production!

item.name: The Kids of Catan
item.comment: Beautiful, solid components. Very attractive and fun game to play with 5 and under.

item.name: King of New York
item.comment: We enjoyed our first play, but I can't say we were wanting to rush out and get a copy. It's a good, solid game, but Tokyo gets played rarely enough that when we do play it, we get the KoT experience. If you've played a ton of KoT, perhaps NY would help.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment: A true winner of a push-your-luck style game. The art is fantastic, the mechanics are simple, and the cards thrown in really make it what it is. Genius system that provides a party-type atmosphere and lots of trash talk. That said, it can be riotously long for what it is, and it is quite devoid of strategy. It is fun to play at times, at others I would pass it up.

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment: It's taken me three plays to truly appreciate Kingdom Builder, but I'm liking the game more each time I play it. The first time you play you just feel a bit lost, even though the rules are so simple. More plays get you a lot more comfortable with the system. I think this is going to become more of a winner as time goes on and expansions continue to be released. *Update* - 20 plays through and I still can't get enough. A true played 10. *Second Update* I've hit 30, but I can't say this is still a 10 anymore. It's starting to lose it's luster for me. But heck, 30 plays!

item.name: Kingdom Builder: Capitol
item.comment: In my opinion, it's an essential expansion. Gives a simple variety to the game and a clever spot for more decisions.

item.name: Kingdom Builder: Nomads
item.comment: More of what I love, and therefore a terrific expansion. Loving the new powers (especially the caravan!), really adds to the base game fluidly, and the new nomad spaces add some extra fun. The new objectives are also very well done. *Update* - I lowered my rating a bit because I've found that some of the new powers cause some AP than usual. Not just that, but I'm just not digging some of the new goals. I wouldn't call the expansion essential.
item.conditiontext: Great condition, stored in original box. I think I still hvae original box.

item.name: Kingdom of Solomon
item.comment: It's a solid worker placement, but nothing is innovative here. I'm still seeing the basic, recognizable mechanics. The theme is okay and this instantly becomes the best Christian game I've played -- and that's awesome. Very excited about that part of this game. The rest, meh.

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment: Fun game and theme with a great mechanic. It strikes me that it can be "figured out", though -- which isn't really a problem. I just haven't figured it out yet!

item.name: Klondike
item.comment: Cool toy and a neat exercise in fun, but it's only good for a few laughs for a couple minutes. Strikes me as more of a toy than a game.

item.name: Krosmaster: Arena
item.comment: Beautiful game and great components, obviously. Good tactical play, but compared to some of my tactical favorites (Summoner Wars, Imperial Assault) it just didn't pack the same kind of punch. But I can step away and see that this is an excellent game and it definitely deserves a strong fanbase.

item.name: Die Kullerbande
item.comment: Cute roll-a-marble-in-a-box game. Excellent fun for a few minutes for kids.

item.name: Labyrinth
item.comment: Not bad at all for a kids game -- does a good job promoting forward thinking -- it's just the presentation is kinda 'blah'. That most likely has to do with the fact that it was released in 1986.

item.name: Labyrinth
item.comment: Good for a few minutes of fun, for sure. I'd like to have a copy of a really over-produced one. I bet it would be awesome.

item.name: The Ladybug Game
item.comment: This is good for perhaps a 2-3 year old. If your kid can count to 10, it's quite useless.

item.name: Lancaster
item.comment: Terrific heavier euro with some really neat mechanics and pleasant worker placement. Love the theme and the components and gameplay do a great job portraying it. Looking forward to another play! This is a winner.

item.name: Las Vegas
item.comment: Great, quick dice-roller with some good decisions. Sure, there are several games like this, but Vegas doesn't pretend to give you something that it shouldn't. It's about VEGAS, and so there's going to be some luck involved. Honestly, adding the white dice raises the game from a 7 to an 8 in my view. I really, really enjoy it with the white dice and it's been a success for me 2-5 players.

item.name: Last Night on Earth 'Revenge of the Dead' Supplement
item.comment: A fine expansion to a terrific game.
item.conditiontext: Cards are a tad bigger than original set. Brand new.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: "We've Got To Go Back!"
item.comment: I enjoyed the scenario - very clever board usage.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: All Hallows Eve
item.comment: Awesome - some memorable occasions came out of this one.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: Growing Hunger
item.comment: Definitely an expansion that was worth buying!

item.name: Last Night on Earth: Stock Up
item.comment: It's okay -- not big on the searchable scenarios but love the new cards.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
item.comment: Instant Top 5 game -- great mechanics, theme, art, scenarios -- we love you Flying Frog! I have to think that at this point this is perhaps the one game in my collection that I will never part with. After almost 30 plays each different game is epic and tells a completely different story than the next. Can't wait for more scenarios!

item.name: Last Will
item.comment: One of the best medium-weight eurogames I've seen in quite a while. The backwards thinking of spending all your money is insanely fun and very clever.

item.name: Last Word
item.comment: Where do I start? The game in itself is almost broken. The random timer is an okay idea, but the nature of the game doesn't allow you to have much time at all to get out a word, especially if you're playing with four or more players. I can't see a scenario where 7 players are quick enough to get one category of words all the way around the table in the time allowed. Also, the mechanics of the game just aren't good -- it's easy to learn, but it's also easy to get stuck with a poor topic or letter. I just didn't like anything about it

item.name: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
item.comment: I'm sure this is a better game than I thought it was the first time I played. So this '6' remains as a placeholder until the next time played, if ever again ..

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.comment: One of the better deck-building games and a better game than Ascension. There are some things that bother me, such as the Ascension-like running cards, but at least they don't refresh every turn and the ideas are somewhat new. The art and theme were very neat.

item.name: Legends of Andor
item.comment: A bit disappointed in this one. I had high hopes from the beginning, but it occurred to me after playing one quest that the next time I played it, it's going to be just too similar. I know that things are going to be in different places, but it's just frightening to think about the replayability factor. Still, it's a solid idea and a wonderful first game from the great Menzel. *Update* - I'm giving it another go-through. I think this would be best to play solo or with people that I know better. *Update 2* - I've played several times solo and I just can't get excited about this. There's just something about this game that I can't get behind. I wish I could!
item.conditiontext: Great condition, played a couple times.

item.name: Leonardo da Vinci
item.comment: Game wasn't bad, I like worker placement. Presentation was poor, though. And it was a tad boring.

item.name: Letters from Whitechapel
item.comment: Yikes! So excited to play this one from the look of it and the graphic design, I was really hooked. Loved everything about it until play started. After almost an hour I was happy to be done, only to find out that there were two more rounds! Oh dear. I'm going to stick with Scotland Yard -- I have yet to find any of it's successors doing any succeeding.

item.name: Lewis & Clark
item.comment: A deckbuilding race game with fantastic art and a nice theme. I love it for the amount of time spent on presentation and art. I think the game is a solid euro. Definitely going to keep and play a few more.

item.name: Liar's Dice
item.comment: Lots of different versions and ways to play. A fun, dice-rolling, educated-guessing good time!

item.name: Libertalia
item.comment: This is a role-selection game and has a bit of blind bidding, and that usually turns me off. But for what it is, I think this was great and it goes up to 6 players and plays rather quickly. The pirate theme is nice, too. I like this one and wouldn't mind owning a copy.

item.name: Lifeboat
item.comment: Lifeboat -- it can go up to a 9 with the right group of friends. While the mechanics aren't super, the game is really, really fun and will leave you with some great memories of backstabbing and joy. It's a bit long for what we're doing here, but you won't care if you're having a great time. *Update* - the more I play the more I like about this little gem.

item.name: Lifeboats
item.comment: Wow, this is just a cutthroat dirty little game. I love me some negotiation games but this one left me with a bad taste in my mouth mostly because of player elimination being entirely possible, and that's a no-no in my book. Really nice production and I'd like to have liked it, but the game seems against you from the start and the battle against others is too susceptible to group think. Not for me!

item.name: Lift it!
item.comment: Much more fun than it should be. Great game design. :) The only issue is that it's more of an activity than a game.

item.name: Ligretto
item.comment: I was introduced to this one back in 2003, and it really is a blast. By far the best speed game I have played, it might take playing it with family to get the most enjoyment out of it, but in itself for such an old game I think it stands up quite well as a true classic. But don't be fooled, this is NOT a 2-player game or even a 3-player game. Play it with 4 (or more with another set).

item.name: Ligretto Dice
item.comment: Absolute chaotic fun. Good filler if you want to race your brain and your fingers. Gets old quick, though.

item.name: Linko!
item.comment: A card game.

item.name: Livingstone
item.comment: Had this on my radar for a long time. Plays out like a family/intro euro. Usually this is right down my alley but it's not getting me too much yet. Definitely going to play a few more times because I enjoy the theme.

item.name: London
item.comment: A neat little game with several clever mechanics thrown together. It's almost what I would consider a light euro once you get the flow of the game going, and I enjoyed the different paths to victory. I've only played Wallace's Runebound, and London was a nice view on what some of his other games might be like. While I'm not crazy about it, I'd certainly enjoy another play anytime.

item.name: Long Shot
item.comment: It's like a more luck-based Winner's Circle in a party-type atmosphere. Very fun! The core mechanics of the horse movement is rather genius.

item.name: Loopin' Louie
item.comment: Great dexterity game for kids. Louie is fantastic and much better than the bumblebee knockoff. Could play for quite a while and enjoy it.

item.name: Lord of the Rings
item.comment: This game is highly underrated -- it's the first co-op game I played, and it was also my first euro-style game as well.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: Friends & Foes
item.comment: Friends & Foes might not be an 'essential' expansion, but the extra boards are fun and provides a new challenge for the game.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.comment: The first FFG card game that actually makes sense to me and makes me want to continue to play it. Many folks have bashed just the base set to me, but honestly I have enjoyed my four solo plays very much. Perhaps it's the theme, but the game works and has already provided some exciting moments! *Update* - now that I am playing this with my 8-year-old son and building decks, it is one of my favorite games to play. *Another update* - Staying power was a problem for me, as I feel like I don't want to invest anymore into new decks and strategies. The original game plus a few expansions seems about right for my level of interest.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game – The Hobbit: Over Hill and Under Hill
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game – The Hunt for Gollum
item.comment: The adventure itself I didn't find very challenging -- didn't take too long to figure out what to do. But I DO love Bilbo ...

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
item.comment: Wow! Terrific two-player game that somehow turns an abstract game into a very thematic experience. Hats off to Dr. Knizia for a wonderful effort here. Love it.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation (Deluxe Edition)
item.comment: Well, I love it even more than the compact version. The components and art are GORGEOUS. The gameplay is just incredibly stellar. I'm still trying to figure out how there is so much theme in this abstract game. Just a superb design.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Duel
item.comment: A nice, light 2-player game that captures the moment nicely and makes a great intro to a fun game night.

item.name: Lords of Vegas
item.comment: The basic mechanics are quite simple, but figuring out a good strategy is quite challenging. It's like mixing Acquire with a whole bunch of luck, but it costs a LOT of money to try that luck out, so it only rears its head so often. Just like Vegas, you can put a lot to chance in this game and end up empty-handed for the most part, but it's quite exhilarating when it works out! Can't say I've played anything like it before! Fun.

item.name: Lords of Vegas: UP!
item.comment: The expansion didn't do a lot for me. It adds an extra player which I don't think is entirely necessary and will be used rarely. The UP! part is not as exciting as I originally envisioned the idea.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment: Whoa, I'm afraid that this ticks WAY too many of the boxes that I like. By far the best game I have played from the 2012 crop so far. Feels like a lot of game in just an hour or so.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep: Scoundrels of Skullport
item.comment: So far, I've played corruption with 6 players. I was surprised that the game could handle six players as well as it did, and I enjoyed the new mechanic. Looking forward to trying the other one.

item.name: Lords of Xidit
item.comment: I'm not sure if this is better than its predecessor, Himalaya. It definitely adds a few more wrinkles, but I wasn't a huge fan of the game. No one can argue that the engine is solid, though, and for a planning game I thought it was well done. But, theme? What was it again?

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment: One of our favorites! Very addictive ... love it with two players but I don't care for it with 4.

item.name: Lost Cities: The Board Game
item.comment: This isn't very good as a two-player game, but when you have 3-4 people and you'd like to play Lost Cities, it's a great option with some good fun.

item.name: Lost Patrol
item.comment: Fantastic! Shoots into my top 10 two-player games pretty quickly. I love the simplicity of the mechanics and that the game can be taken along quite easily. This game has survived the test of time and I imagine it will be around here for quite a while, as well.

item.name: Lost Valley: The Yukon Goldrush 1896
item.comment: Convoluted. Too busy and tons of bits everywhere. LOVE the theme, love the idea. Wanted badly to make it work. Badly ... just can't do it. Have to let it go. I'm glad this game exists, and I credit the designers very much for trying. But it doesn't work for me

item.name: Lost Worlds
item.comment: While I can imagine this being a HUGE hit back in the day, the system works and everything, but it becomes a bit of a bore after a while. Ingenious ideas, though, and completely inventive!

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: I know it works and that it's just 16 cards or whatever. A decent filler for sure. I just don't understand the fascination with it. It's solid and fine, but I'm just not that excited when I sit down to play. I view it as a time-filler that works well. A solid experience for what it is, not a great one. *Update* - okay, it's fun ...

item.name: Love Letter: The Hobbit – The Battle of the Five Armies
item.comment: The best of the Love Letters that I have played so far.

item.name: Luchador! Mexican Wrestling Dice
item.comment: Here's a fun dice-roller that includes a 3D ring for extra theme! It's also serviceable in that it creates a space to throw your dice and hit the other players' dice out. This is a fun game that doesn't last too long and can be a true winner in a raucous atmosphere.

item.name: Luna
item.comment: One of the best euros of 2010 -- Feld does it again for me in back-to-back years (Macao). Luna is intimidating at first, and does lend to a bit of AP due to future-planning, but the experience is totally worth it. Just an excellent game, and gorgeous to boot! *Update* Quickly becoming one of my favorite euros of all time.

item.name: Macao
item.comment: Macao has to be one of my favorite euros from 2009. Love the dice mechanic in it and all the different paths to victory. I could play it many times and still enjoy it. I guess I could wish for a different theme, but hey -- in this instance, the mechanic is so great I can live with it. Also plays great with 2-4. A stronger theme would put this to a 9.

item.name: Machi Koro
item.comment: Rather disappointing after all the hype. The base game was a bit light and was okay. The expansion really ruined the game for me. So there you go. I think it's a clever implementation of Settlers, but I'd rather play Settlers.

item.name: Machi Koro: Harbor Expansion
item.comment: This kind of spoiled the experience for me. I feel like Machi Koro needs to stay as a light game. This put too much on the simple system for its own good, IMO.

item.name: Mad Gab
item.comment: While quite fun in the first few minutes, nearing the end I found myself thinking "that's it?" The cards were relatively easy to solve and I doubt I would ever request pulling it out again.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment: I'm a believer. GREAT integration of theme, terrific components, engaging, fun, creative. Vlaada's best yet. Solo value seems immense.

item.name: The Magic Labyrinth
item.comment: Gorgeous memory game for kids. Incredible production. Really a lot of fun, especially if you have kids in your family that love memory.

item.name: Magic: The Gathering
item.comment: I missed the initial banzai of the game, but I've played several times online now with the Duels of the Planeswalkers sets, and I've enjoyed it. I think there's a bit too much randomness involved and too much hoping to draw a card that you need, but the system is very sound and it's a lot of fun. *Update* - picked up the Red and Green decks from the Duels of the Planeswalkers. Son and I are having fun with them.

item.name: Magical Athlete
item.comment: LOL. This is a game somehow, and it was a game that I enjoyed. Scary. But really, some goofy, broken fun here. Great 2 a.m. game.

item.name: Magnum Opus
item.comment: There's some clever things going on here. I'd like to try it a couple more times. The theme and box art maybe is holding it back? It's a good game.

item.name: Make 'n' Break Party
item.comment: Many party games fall flat either because what you're doing isn't fun, or what you're doing might be fun but lasts too long. Make and Break Party has you doing a building exercise that is fun and doesn't take a long time, keeps everyone involved, and is involved and exciting. A winner. I don't recommend playing the entire board, though. It can be a bit lengthy ...

item.name: Mall of Horror
item.comment: One of the best 5-6 player games I've played and perhaps my favorite negotiation game. Truly underrated. With a fun group even more fun!

item.name: Mamma Mia!
item.comment: Fun, easy to learn, about pizza. Three of my favorite phrases right there! The memory mechanic is different for sure, but I'm not sure I like it too much because I am truly horrible at it!

item.name: Mammut
item.comment: Neat theme and kind of felt like a lite version of Ra. Very thematic in scoring where Ra might not feel as attached. I guess the only thing that took the game down a bit is the selection process -- while I think that after a few plays I could perceive it better, it seemed like it was just really, really difficult to get exactly what you wanted. But some neat ideas here and a fun one!

item.name: Manhattan
item.comment: It's fun, but there's something about the board that just doesn't click with me. I feel more like I'm playing something very abstract opposed to building a city. I enjoyed the play, but afterward I knocked it off of my wishlist.

item.name: Manila
item.comment: Intense gambling game. Played great with five players, very quick and fun. I really enjoyed the first play. It's one of those coins-are-victory points kind of games, so every turn you're wagering your points.

item.name: Mansions of Madness
item.comment: One jerky play not enough to rate or even attempt to comment. Let's say it wasn't the best first impression but it deserves another shot most certainly.

item.name: Maori
item.comment: Beautiful game -- unfortunately I am not very good at it and I don't really care for it either. But very nice production and gorgeous art, wish I would have enjoyed it.

item.name: Martinique
item.comment: I enjoyed my first play of Martinique. Clever mechanics! Underrated game IMO. Replay value is high.

item.name: Master Builder
item.comment: Holy cow -- the event cards in this game can COMPLETELY screw you over. Even then, I still found it fun. And those buildings are insanely awesome. My feeling is that two-player is not great, though. Four was rather fun but I found it interesting that the contracts ran out. Have to try with three.

item.name: Master of Rules
item.comment: I just don't care for card games like this -- it just seems like such a flimsy design to me. I don't see how it could have any kind of sustained interest or replayability.

item.name: Medici
item.comment: I was let down a bit here. The quality and design of the board was poor, and the meeples could have been cubes and worked better. The game itself was a fun bidding game that used victory points as the bid, very intriguing. Things went a bit slow for my liking. Then again, we did play with six, so perhaps a lower number is it's best bet.

item.name: Medina (second edition)
item.comment: It was well-hyped and respected by BGG, Tom Vasel liked it, and it looked so pretty. And the components! But the game REALLY fell flat for us. It just has no direction. The rules are theme are quite soulless. This one is not for me, and was traded away.

item.name: Meepile
item.comment: It's a big meeple that you can stack meeples on. Meepile has become the start-player mechanism for us when we play Carcassonne. Fun diversion for not a lot of $.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: I enjoy Battlelore a bit better, but I can see myself playing games of this with my son when he gets older, and using it as a teaching tool to learn about military history. What other games can boast that? Memoir is a ton of fun and if you can afford all the expansions, well worth it. *Update* - I've decided that I like Memoir better than Battlelore! The system is easier, quicker, and cleaner.

item.name: Memoir '44: Campaign Book Volume 1
item.comment: Love the idea of successful or failed objectives carrying over consequences into the next battle. The reserve idea and victory events add flavor. I already loved Memoir '44, but this injects even more juice into the system -- loving it so far.

item.name: Memoir '44: Eastern Front
item.comment: Overall some fun scenarios and challenging maps, but nothing spectacular. Love the winter maps and some of the new terrain is creative. New armies are creative but not as much as Pacific Theater.

item.name: Memoir '44: Hedgerow Hell
item.comment: Got to play Hedgerow Hell with Richard Borg himself looking on! Excellent fun. I continue to enjoy the Overlord format -- again, not one that I would want to do all the time, but just excellent variation on the game. The supply trucks were a neat idea and used many times! Terrific map with the action in the middle being the highlight.

item.name: Memoir '44: Pacific Theater
item.comment: This is just an excellent expansion -- new troop rules that are creative, thematic, and a blast to play with, new terrain that puts a lot of tactics into the game, and great scenarios. I love this expansion.

item.name: Memoir '44: Tigers in the Snow
item.comment: A well-done Overlord scenario, full of fun and excitement. I really liked the Tiger tanks and the threat of the Russian tanks on the right flank. Looking forward to trying the reverse side.

item.name: Memoir '44: Winter/Desert Board Map
item.comment: Beautiful maps ...

item.name: Merchant of Venus
item.comment: One play on the old Avalon Hill version. It was a bit long and a bit cumbersome, and the bits just weren't up to a good standard. I imagine the second edition will be tons better. The fun is definitely there, and I like pick-up and deliver.

item.name: Merchant of Venus (second edition)
item.comment: This is superior to the first in graphics and perhaps gameplay, although I don't have eyes to play the advanced version. The base game itself is good enough in my mind, for when you are of mood. It's probably the first pick-up-and-deliver game, and it might be the best.

item.name: Metropolys
item.comment: Excellent game! Great combination of auctions, tile-laying, and area control. Excellent production. I can't even put my finger on why I like it so much. One of the most underrated games out there. Incredible how great a game you can have with just a small page of rules.

item.name: Mexican Train
item.comment: It is what it is. Dominoes and train pieces are nice in this edition, but the game is still pretty devoid of fun.

item.name: Mice and Mystics
item.comment: As a straight-up game, I'm not sure it's entirely special or not. It's certainly beautiful, with gorgeous miniatures and very nice graphic design and art. But the stories DO make it special, and with it being co-operative, it makes it very fun to team up with children. They really get into the stories and enjoy it, as do I. Plaid Hat is known for their storylines in their games, and this is proof positive of that. Fun game and I look forward to expansions.

item.name: Middle-Earth Quest
item.comment: Epic, and worth a play or two certainly. If you're in the mood for a longer game, it's a great option.

item.name: Milestones
item.comment: Unfortunately, our first play I wasn't too impressed. To me, it seemed that I kept doing the same thing over and over again, and the board was just very abstract in nature. Maybe there's a good game here, but I didn't see it.

item.name: Mission: Red Planet
item.comment: Citadels with a board/area control. Having more than just the role selection in the game makes this one a winner for me. Also adore the theme. *Update* - not sure what I was thinking. Played recently and there's no way to plan your turn due to all the randomness. It's a fun idea and a cool implementation, but I was feeling more frustrated than anything.

item.name: MLB SportsClix
item.comment: Neat idea, weak execution -- the bases are a pain to move, and the fold-out paper baseball diamond is a real pain.

item.name: Mondo
item.comment: Excellent family game that I enjoyed quite a bit although I happened to not be good at it (same problem as Galaxy Trucker) -- but it has a lot of neat ideas and I like to know that there are some quality speed games out there.

item.name: Money!
item.comment: Nice production and a good little set collection game. Supports 4-5 the best. A fun filler that I can recommend.

item.name: Monopoly Deal Card Game
item.comment: Eh. Just not that exciting. Much rather play a different card game.

item.name: Monster Derby
item.comment: This game is a lot of fun, and I think Jeff really nailed getting the personalities of these guys to reflect the what happens on the table. I've played it through 2 players to 8, and I think 4-5 is probably the sweet spot. Keeping this one and great for the parties.

item.name: Monster Factory
item.comment: Monster Factory is actually my second-favorite Donald X game, right after Dominion. There's not much to it, but the art is GREAT and it's fun to put the monsters together. Fun tile-laying option for kids and adults.

item.name: Monsters Menace America
item.comment: We loved the pieces, but I'm afraid that with the clunky attack system and the failed end-game, the game might be broken.

item.name: Monty Python Fluxx
item.comment: Eh.

item.name: Mord im Arosa
item.comment: Cube tower uncertainty and deduction rolled into one. Easy to play and fun, although there's a good amount of feeling helpless going on. Probably a lot better to understand after several playthroughs.

item.name: Moto Grand Prix
item.comment: This was a lot of fun, and the minis were gorgeous. I also love the mechanic of tilting the miniature on it's side to represent a turn. But race games are race games, in the end.

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment: It's quick, it's okay, but didn't hold our attention or desire long to stay.

item.name: Munchkin
item.comment: No sir.

item.name: Munchkin Booty
item.comment: I guess the main problem I have with Munchkin is the basis of the game itself. It's just random draws from a stack of cards, with no way to prepare for future turns or have any idea what's coming or going. And games that have a variable ending time really bug me too.

item.name: Municipium
item.comment: Enjoyable worker-placement experience. Need to have some more plays to fully understand how it works. *Update* - I must admit, Municipium is starting to grow on me. It's an enjoyable worker placement with just enough luck for me to like it, and of course, it wouldn't be half as fun without the "asshats"!

item.name: Mush! Mush!: Snow Tails 2
item.comment: The get-up-and-go racing is so much better than the mind-numbing Snow Tails.
item.conditiontext: Great condition, played twice. All pieces intact.

item.name: Navegador
item.comment: If this is a good indicator of rondel games, I will have to pass. It just felt like we were taking turns doing the same thing. It was balanced enough, almost too balanced actually, to the point where I didn't feel I was doing anything important several turns. I actually started to get BORED near the end. Perhaps i'm not a fan of economic games, but this one was one of the worst I've played.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex!
item.comment: It's mostly an abstract style of game, and the first play did not impress me. But after getting an idea of how to play, my second play was quite enjoyable! I don't know what changed, but yeah -- really liked the second play!

item.name: New World: A Carcassonne Game
item.comment: It's hard to put my finger on this one. I thought it was fun, but there is a lot that bothers me as well. You have to go into it with the mindset that small things are better. And I recommend not playing it with 5 players, because there's absolutely no way to plan any kind of power move. By the time it gets to your turn again, the surveyors have likely moved on and you have likely been removed from the board. I'd like to try it with 3-4 players, though.

item.name: The New Yorker: Cartoon Caption Game
item.comment: Write a caption for the picture and then play Apples to Apples. Fun and very straight-forward for a creative group. It was enjoyable. I will say that I would really enjoy a Far Side version of this game.

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: A great game, holds 2-4 brilliantly. I feel like I should make it a personal mission to make sure everyone plays this. I like it that much.

item.name: Niagara
item.comment: This might be on the top of my list of "games I want to like and I'm trying as hard as I can to". After playing it quite wrong the first time due to the hideous rulebook, I tried it again this month and even with playing it right, I came away with an 'eh'. It's gorgeous and family-oriented and light-strategy -- all things I LOVE in my eurogames. But I can't help feeling that it could go on FOREVER, and the aggravation involved in trying to get your boats back is at times hideous.

item.name: Niagara: Diamond Joe
item.comment: This adds another jewel out there to grab. He came into play a couple of times, and it probably did speed things up a bit, but I don't think Joe adds much to the game. A fun addition.

item.name: Nightfall
item.comment: One of the better deckbuilding games I've played. Very creative mechanics and although it does feel like something is wrong or not developed enough, a good solid game and a lot better than most deckbuilders.

item.name: Ninja Versus Ninja
item.comment: An excellent abstract with dice disguised as a kids game. At its core, it's actually one of my favorite abstracts out there because of the dice, you really have some fun decisions to make. The pieces are terrific, too.

item.name: Ninjato
item.comment: A quick worker placement/push your luck game in an hour with a terrific theme and artwork? Sign me up. Can't wait to give this one another try after the first run-through. Components are terrific and the game plays smooth and quick.

item.name: No Thanks!
item.comment: Quick, fun filler. For what it is, it's excellent.

item.name: Notre Dame
item.comment: Another fantastic Feld -- his games are consistently 8s for me. Notre Dame does a good job with drafting and punishment, as you really have to make agonizing choices with the cards you are dealt. Points or rat infestation? The choice is yours.

item.name: Numbers League: Adventures in Addiplication
item.comment: The kids really love the art -- the game is pretty cool too.

item.name: Nuns on the Run
item.comment: The reverse of Scotland Yard, the concept works but it is a bit hard to learn and it's also quite difficult at times to guess where the best place to go is. Still makes for a lot of fun and stress!

item.name: O Zoo le Mio
item.comment: It's a fun cross between Zooloretto and Carcassonne, and the components are really neat. But something about the way the game goes, whether its the bidding or the art on the tiles, bothers me. I'm happy I played it, though. Oh, and for the record, this is one of the worst box covers in history.

item.name: Odin's Ravens
item.comment: A fun race game that plays in the style of Lost Cities. Good mix of tactics, luck, and strategy. Another success with my wife!

item.name: One Night Ultimate Werewolf
item.comment: To me, a waste of time. I'd rather play the longer Werewolf and get something out of the experience. But I do like Mr. Summerer. *update*- did I write that? This game is fun!

item.name: One Night Ultimate Werewolf Daybreak
item.comment: More fun, but I think the base set is just a bit better and less 'weird'. Logging plays under One Night Ultimate Werewolf.

item.name: Onirim
item.comment: Oh, yes. One of the best co-ops out there, and just in a deck of cards. Simple setup and fun both solo and two-player, Onirim is an absolute winner!

item.name: Operation
item.comment: Although I give some credit to the new sound effects version.

item.name: Operation: Maccabee
item.comment: Very light, fun, creative design. The mechanics aren't going to knock you over but this one just gets points for being such an awesome idea. You're spinning dreidels and liberating concentration camps! Awesome.

item.name: Othello
item.comment: Old classic that gets pulled out once in a blue moon.

item.name: Pack & Stack
item.comment: Fun, neat mix of speed and puzzle-solving. Instant hit with my lovely female and I'd really enjoy playing it more often as well. Unfortunately my first play was interrupted by my darling one-year-old, so I will have to wait for a second play to rate. *Update* - thanks Cameron and the Rancho gamers for this great gift! Played a second time at home with the family and it's a hit. Realy like the use of dice with the puzzle aspect.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: The more I play this, the more entertainment I get out of it. On the Brink is a tremendous expansion. Plus, the solo play is just incredible. What a terrific system!

item.name: Pandemic: Contagion
item.comment: It takes the theme and does nothing with it, for which I am very sad. The game is okay, but nothing that I would pull out and desire to play.

item.name: Pandemic: On the Brink
item.comment: One of the best expansions ever created. While repeated plays of Pandemic could seem similar over time, On the Brink never allows that to happen again. Both the Mutation and the Virulent Strain are just nasty and a whole lot of fun.

item.name: Pandemic: The Cure
item.comment: What started out as a lot of fun has perhaps peaked somehow. Have to play some more before deciding.
item.conditiontext: Great condition. Dice circle was replaced from publisher.

item.name: Panic Station
item.comment: Great ideas, poor execution. There's no better way to say it than that. Definitely some promise, but I prefer others in the genre.

item.name: Pantheon
item.comment: There's some things I really like about Pantheon. You can tell it's the same designer as Stone Age, as you have a progressive build throughout the game and many strategic options to take. I liked it just fine. I guess the main trouble I had with it was that the theme seemed very uninspired. The feet meeples were rather lame, and the art and board didn't really get me excited at all. The box is HUGE and certainly doesn't have to be. I wish that the presentation had a bit more and I could see myself purchasing it and enjoying it more. The game itself though, is good, not great, and that in the long run is what will hold up the purchase.

item.name: Paris Connection
item.comment: Solid, light filler for the Chicago Express crowd. I'd play this over Chicago Express and its ilk just because it's a quicker way to play it and I'm not a huge fan of these games in general. But a neat idea and fun for what it was.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Skull & Shackles – Base Set
item.comment: Easily the surprise of the year. I really can't stop playing this one. And when you get a build on a character and keep him going, the game is quite addictive. Great mechanics. Solo play is also enjoyable.

item.name: Pay Dirt
item.comment: A good, solid, medium-weight euro with a theme that is quite bland. It gets a high score, though, because it is quite a good game. I enjoyed ramping up my engine and grabbing points, but there's really nothing that would make me desire to really play it again.

item.name: Pecking Order
item.comment: Quick, fun attack game with a neat theme and solid mechanics. Great filler or couples game. One of my favorite two-player games.

item.name: Peloponnes
item.comment: Excellent, quick civ-building game with a lot of charm. Needs to be published by a real company because there's a lot to like here! Please see my blog for in-depth review.

item.name: Perry Rhodan: The Cosmic League
item.comment: Quickly morphing into one of our favorite two-player games. Beautiful presentation and enough fun choices and experiences to fill up a half-hour. The cards can certainly go against you, but being a short game it's not really a flaw in my mind. You can still get a good strategy going with what is provided to you.

item.name: Phoenicia
item.comment: A bit clunky and unattractive both mechanically and production-wise.

item.name: Pick Picknic
item.comment: Cute. Doesn't seem to be much there strategy-wise, but a cute and short filler.

item.name: Picknick Panik
item.comment: The kids love it ... at its heart its a trick-taking game easy enought for a child to enjoy and strategize. For that purpose, its excellent.

item.name: Pickomino
item.comment: Played online. Just don't see the attraction so much. Seems to be very difficult to get any of the higher tiles.

item.name: Pictionary Junior
item.comment: Good for the 4+ kids out there.

item.name: Pictomania
item.comment: Clever twist on drawing games ... quite tough yojr first time but some really interesting ideas here.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth
item.comment: After a long absence, I really enjoyed another play of this with the expansion. Fun decisions and just gorgeous components and board. Now one of my favorite games. Enjoyed the book immensely!

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Set
item.comment: It's wonderful having a fifth player in there, but of course along with that, there is a bit of extra time added to the game. So while the game was a bit long, it was also a blast. The new "Crusades" spot is essential and much used. Liked it very much.

item.name: Pirate King
item.comment: It's a variant on Monopoly, but it's gorgeously dressed up and has some of the best art I've seen. While the wind die can sometimes drive you absolutely mad, the game is light and fun enough to not put you off.

item.name: Pirate Versus Pirate
item.comment: Very disappointing sequel to the fun Ninja v. Ninja. Opposed to some good decisions in Ninja, Pirate v. Pirate has almost no decisions at all and is basically a big three-player free-for-all. Will not be purchasing.

item.name: Pirate's Cove
item.comment: Now here's a game that you play if you want to have fun. Get into the theme and roll those dice. Fun light strategy mayhem. A lot of luck, but it doesn't bother me in the least because I was having a good time. *Update* - played with an older more experienced crowd and found out what the fuss was all about. After that session I'm a solid fan of Pirate's Cove -- it was tense and exciting the whole time. Plus, we played with five players, which is certainly an upgrade over three.

item.name: Pirates vs. Dinosaurs
item.comment: Unfortunately, the art and cool components is not enough to make this a good game. The rounds and flow of the game just didn't seem to connect with me. Just too many problems to list.

item.name: PitchCar
item.comment: One of the best dexterity games out there. Tons of fun. Unfortunately, also tons of $.

item.name: PitchCar Mini
item.comment: So it certainly looks like the kids do better than the adults in the Mini version! Not sure what it is, but my son destroyed me. I wish these weren't so bloody expensive. I don't like it as much as the big version, though.

item.name: Poker
item.comment: I'll always play Poker if I have to, but I would choose Texas Hold-Em above all variations. Never been really big into it, though. I do think it's fun.

item.name: Poseidon's Kingdom
item.comment: Scintillating components and a creative mechanic makes this one a true winner. Unlike some of the Fragor brothers' games that I've played, this one has no problems of getting a bit stale because of all the dice involved. Quick and fun, great family game and looks awesome on the table.

item.name: Pow Wow
item.comment: Adding up totals on feathers and guessing on a number. To me, it would make more sense to have more variables out there besides just the one on your head, but it's a good party deduction game for what it is.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: There's a lot to like about Power Grid. I enjoyed the auction stage, I really like the management of money for the three stages, and I like the graphics and presentation of the game. This is a serious winner for me and I can't wait to play again! With 3 I found it quite fun, with 6 it is enjoyable, but there is a lot of waiting between turns. Certainly bad to be leader in a 6-player game!

item.name: Power Grid: The First Sparks
item.comment: Honestly, I think I enjoy this a bit more than the original. Taking the auctions out makes the game much shorter, it works well with six people, and the theme is quite fun. The art is also outstandingly funny. First Sparks is a winner!

item.name: Powerboats
item.comment: Another one of those easy-to-learn games that end up being a ton of fun. Easily in my Top 5 racing games of all time. Really, it's that good!

item.name: The Princes of Florence
item.comment: This is an excellent example of a game that, in my opinion, is a classic in every sense of the word but has been replaced and redone to make it better in the future. I recognize fully that the game was great in its time. But playing it 14 years later after release I just can't get into it. I feel like Colosseum, who PoF is always compared to, is actually quite a different game indeed. Scoring throughout really changes the way to play. A good game by all accounts. Would have played the crap out of it 14 years ago.

item.name: Pro Wrestler
item.comment: Champions of the Galaxy has a better system, art, and storyline -- but it was something to pass the time back in the day.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: Having already played games like Race for the Galaxy and Endeavor, a lot of the mechanics used in Puerto Rico stood out to me and felt familiar. Very good game and it was neat seeing the role selection and how it was used.

item.name: Puzzle Strike
item.comment: Eh -- I didn't like it at all. The chips are lame and it's basically Dominion with a few different attack cards thrown in. I didn't like the gem thing, either. It even had purple felt bags! A stinker for me.

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment: I am in love with the idea, but the game itself feels a bit short and too light for what I'd like. Hoping for an expansion that makes it a bit better, but I really dig the concept. Played again with experienced players and found it more fun. Also, the track should always be on 20. If you go into it with a silly mindset, you'll enjoy it.

item.name: Quarriors! Quaxos Promo Cards
item.comment: I really don't think it adds much to the game. It might just be reflective of my opinion of the game but they don't seem to make much of a difference. Sold on eBay for $30 ...

item.name: Quarriors! Rise of the Demons
item.comment: Didn't seem like it added much to the game -- I feel like it could have been placed in a bigger box expansion as a side course to a main dish, opposed to being the main feature. The new demon is neat, though, and quite powerful.

item.name: Quarto!
item.comment: Not a big fan of abstracts, but this one is very clever. Picking the piece for your opponent is pretty fun.

item.name: Queen's Necklace
item.comment: It's okay -- not a fan of the art but the theme is neat. Wouldn't mind a play anytime but not good enough to keep on the shelf.

item.name: Quelf
item.comment: Insane, crazy game ... played well with 6. Now, finding the right people to play with is a bit difficult!

item.name: Quicksand
item.comment: It's fun, and I'm glad I have another game to support 6, but things just get so congested near the end I soured a bit on it. I'm thinking that with 3-4 it's probably best. *Update* - yup, I was right. Even two players is quite fun.

item.name: Qwirkle
item.comment: Clever variant to Scrabble. I like it much more than Scrabble -- but really, there isn't much to it. My son seemed to enjoy the play, though, and ask for a rematch immediately! I like that it can handle a big number of folks.

item.name: Qwixx
item.comment: This is the Rixx version, given to me by the great Hanibal. Fun dice collection game. A winner no matter where you go.

item.name: Ra
item.comment: I love the decisions and the drama in this one -- my favorite auction-style game.

item.name: Ra: The Dice Game
item.comment: A lot simpler and straightforward than the original, but just not as fun. Played as two players, I would imagine the rating would be .5 higher with more. I guess it serves well as a good filler, but I have plenty of those.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment: It started out AWESOME for me and then trailed off a bit ... we'll see where it goes in another few plays. The online client at keldon.net is gorgeous and gives the game some life for me. But honestly, the game is still so bloody confusing, and that certainly takes away from the enjoyment. ** Now another recent play in the books and I have to admit I enjoyed it. Maybe with almost 10 plays in the books I am getting used to it?

item.name: The Rainbow Fish Game
item.comment: I know there's a small amount of decision-making here, but the kids love it, so I have fun too.

item.name: Raj
item.comment: For a quick little 10-minute diversion, Raj was really enjoyable. So easy to pick up and play, very simple idea, and it works really well. One of the better fillers out there.

item.name: Rallyman
item.comment: Solid racing game, one of the better ones I've played. Not a huge fan of the timing element, what can I say -- I prefer a competitive race format better.

item.name: Ranking
item.comment: A very entertaining variant of Apples to Apples that can be hilarious if the right questions come up with the right crowd!

item.name: Rattlebones
item.comment: Cute ideas and components. I feel like this is one of those games that starts a great idea and doesn't quite finish it. No doubt this will be looked back as the predecessor to some pretty neat games using this dice-changing mechanic.

item.name: RattleSnake
item.comment: Half the game is playing with the magnets.

item.name: Rattus
item.comment: A short and sweet euro in a small box that ticks a lot of the boxes that I like. Neat role-selection and area control aspects. The rat tiles even add in a bit of luck, so this is a true winner. *Update* - the expansion makes it even better and it's quickly becoming a huge favorite.

item.name: Rattus: Africanus
item.comment: Just to be able to expand the game to 6 players makes me happy. I'm not big on the cards, they seem a bit gimmicky, but the new roles that don't use the cards are great! I love Rattus.

item.name: Rattus: Pied Piper
item.comment: What an expansion should be. Excellent mix of new roles and fun.

item.name: Rattus: Spiel 2010 Bonus Cards
