item.comment: More fun for Rattus equals a good rating. Love all the roles.

item.name: Ratuki
item.comment: Fun speed game that I knew absolutely nothing about, but we're really enjoying it! Thanks to Eric for the gift.

item.name: Red November
item.comment: A fun little co-op that has a few clever twists to it. The theme is ripe as well, as zany a theme as it is. Definitely should have been published in a bigger box, though. *update* - Some of my first-play fears were realized in my second play. So much randomness! It still was fun, but the game itself is more of a "collect items, hope you don't lose them to randomness, wait till something bad happens, fix it, die"

item.name: Red7
item.comment: A solid, clever trick-taking game. There are many of these, but this does stand above most. Still, I would prefer a couple others above it.

item.name: Reiner Knizia's Decathlon
item.comment: Fun, FREE dice-rolling game that we found to be very creative and provide a whole lot of enjoyment. For a sheet of paper and 8 dice, one of the best PnP options I've seen on the internet so far.

item.name: Relic Runners
item.comment: Days of Wonder usually hits me strong, but this one didn't get me at all. The theme was good and components are always great, but I didn't enjoy the game much. It was quite vanilla.

item.name: The Resistance
item.comment: A great social deduction game. It's fast and contains a lot of bang for a small package. Looking forward to trying the included expansion, as my initial impression is that it will be very difficult for the Resistance to win with the basic game (that was with 10 players). *Update* - played now 8 times, and have really enjoyed it! The plot cards are fun but it seems that it would be very hard for the spies to win with them in play. Overall, I've found it to be about even in who wins. A fabulous filler and its becoming a favorite.

item.name: The Resistance: Avalon
item.comment: I believe this to be better than the original, because I like the ending decision on who the traitor was. Clever manipulation of the system at hand.

item.name: Reverse Charades
item.comment: It was a fun activity. I thought it went over quite well, but in the end, it IS charades. I'd rather play Time's Up.

item.name: Revolution!
item.comment: The biggest surprise of my gaming life? Perhaps. I never expected to enjoy a game by Steve Jackson so much. It's blind bidding, but it doesn't annoy me like some of those do. Quite fun trying to guess what others will be doing.

item.name: Revolution! The Palace
item.comment: Six players actually worked! That really is a revolution. I imagine that it's best with 5 players but it was a well-done expansion. Only thing holding it back is the cost versus what you get. Thanks so much for the gift Kirk and family!

item.name: Revolver
item.comment: Pretty dang fantastic two-player game. Very thematic, the art is great, and both sides play and feel differently. And did I mention it has some really fun decisions?

item.name: Rialto
item.comment: Somewhat good, somewhat forgettable. The thing holding up purchase is wondering if I would ever want to play it again?

item.name: Ribbit
item.comment: The Turtle game is a hit with all. Clever card play and a quick fun presentation.

item.name: Riff Raff
item.comment: Very creatively-built, exciting dexterity game. One of the best built games I've seen on the market. Fabulous concept and delivery. Really enjoy this one!

item.name: Ring-O Flamingo
item.comment: Is this for children or adults? Either way, a hilarious fun time. What a great concept!

item.name: Risk
item.comment: My second-favorite game growing up has become quite stale over the years. :) But I played it more than 20 times in my youth.

item.name: Risk Legacy
item.comment: The game is Risk with some accouterments. But the Legacy system is engaging and fun. Will check back. *Update* turns out the idea itself was grand, and I enjoyed the played very much in spite of Risk and more because of Legacy. Now with Pandemic Legacy, I see what the system could be like, and it is amazing.

item.name: Risk: Plants vs. Zombies
item.comment: The components are quite poor. We gave it a shot but while I thought the theme was enjoyable, the game was still Risk. Who'd have thought?

item.name: River Dragons
item.comment: Great job on this remake. I never played the original but the component upgrade on this doesn't give me a reason to. The game is clever and fun, but is not outstandingly-different enough to make me want to own it or replace other games with it. Would happily play again, though.

item.name: RoadZters
item.comment: This was actually much better than expected! The Z-ball is great and the components are top notch. Lots of fun.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment: Every once in a while a cooperative game comes along that steals my heart for months. Robinson Crusoe is that game. The presentation, art, and mechanics are all wonderfully integrated into a fantastic presentation that is certainly not easy to win. There is a lot going on, but when you look at the amount of missions you get in the game and how varied everything is, you could play this for quite a while. Great game!

item.name: Rock the Beat
item.comment: Fun party game that can support a ton of people. Not sure if it really is that good of a game but certainly a lot of fun to play. Switching motions around can be a bit confusing.

item.name: Roll For It! Deluxe Edition
item.comment: Nothing but obvious decisions, mindless rolling. At least it's quick.

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy
item.comment: I liked Race okay, but it didn't last around very long for me. This one didn't grab me at all. I think I'd prefer Race, and since I love dice games that should say something.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: Growing up, I used to love Yahtzee, a game I still enjoy on occasion. Something about rolling and hoping you get what you need. RttA is a great graduation of that system and I enjoy it very much! There's also nothing like rolling some skulls and attacking your friends. Turns out this is a very enjoyable solo timekill as well - top score of 79 solo!

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Iron Age
item.comment: Of course, the automatic thing you do is to compare it to its older brother. There's really not much to compare here, this is a completely different game. I enjoyed it, but something seemed a bit off, and I think it's just that I didn't find it as "fun" as the original. I'd need to have some more plays now that I'm familiar with the new rules.

item.name: Rolling Freight
item.comment: A neat idea and I like the dice-rolling, but the game was subpar for me, and I didn't feel very engaged. Aside from the dice, it was very standard for the train genre, one that I am truly bored with.

item.name: Roma
item.comment: Roma is a solid two-player card game that uses dice in Feldian ways in order to get points. I think it's a solid game and one that deserves a spot on the shelf.

item.name: Rory's Story Cubes
item.comment: Neat little creative exercise that's easy and fun to take with you on trips. It's nice to listen to your kids make up stories with them.

item.name: Rukshuk
item.comment: This might be the most difficult dexterity game I've played. The rocks are cleverly used, and the system is very creative. Just not sure how often this will be plucked out and played.

item.name: Rumis
item.comment: I like it with 2-4. With more fun options abounding, this one is getting pushed to the back a bit. And after playing Ubongo 3D at the con, Rumis has been gifted away to a favorite couple of ours.

item.name: Run, Fight, or Die!
item.comment: A fun, Yahtzee game that has you managing a steady stream of threat on a personalized board. Some clever card pulls and player powers. I think it's inventive and fun, but not sure how much staying power it is.

item.name: Runebound (Second Edition)
item.comment: Well, well -- I bought this for the solo aspect and haven't been disappointed one bit. If I need to have an evening to unwind and wrap myself in a story through gaming, this is the one that gets pulled off the shelf. Several games are playable with solo play, but if you use the Threat Track, I feel that Runebound is in the Top 3 of what I have seen out there. Some choice expansions make the game even better. And of course, I'm a big fan of Terrinoth.
item.conditiontext: Upgraded components include printed out and laminated Threat Track for solo play and replaced all cardboard gem tokens with colored "pebbles" from Michael's.

item.name: Runebound: Relics of Legend
item.comment: If you need more items and such, here they are.

item.name: Runebound: The Dark Forest
item.comment: Good mix of new cards and situations, that's about all it is and all its worth.

item.name: Runebound: The Scepter of Kyros
item.comment: The best Runebound expansion card set I've played with yet. The Giants change the game quite radically, removing the red markers entirely and building up to a final big giant showdown. It's a nice variant.

item.name: Runebound: The Terrors of the Tomb
item.comment: Good mix of new cards and situations, that's about all it is and all its worth.

item.name: Runewars
item.comment: Runewars is a fantastically-produced strategic war game. There is a lot of depth to it, from the factions to the seasons to the resource juggling. Excellent, and as long as it stays under three hours, tremendous. (ONLY INTERESTED IN REVISED EDITION)

item.name: Ruse & Bruise
item.comment: A bit too many rounds. Not too enjoyable, either.

item.name: Rush n' Crush
item.comment: I like racing games, and I would have thought I would love destroying other racers, but there are several numbers involved in the destruction that you have to try to remember, and there doesn't seem to be a set scale to decide which damage hits. This means you are forced to open the rulebook every time you want to destroy someone. It's just really annoying for me, and takes the fun out of the "advanced" version, which is the one I would be interested in playing.

item.name: Russian Railroads
item.comment: There's no doubt RR is a good game. I like it ... but something is keeping me from listing it as a favorite euro. The way the tracks operate is, to me, confusing. And in repeat plays I am struggling with not being a tad bored with the tracks and what to do. I want it to be a classic! I do. I'll keep on playing and see what happens.

item.name: Saboteur
item.comment: What a surprise! Very fun and quick. I can see how after repeated plays things could get a bit stale, but I enjoy it for now. For a light-BSG feel, though, I think The Resistance ticks those boxes quite well over this one.

item.name: Safranito
item.comment: I enjoy the flicking mechanic of Safranito, and of course the gorgeous art, but when it comes to the trading, I find it quite difficult to be able to strategie at all with your discs being flicked around all the time. Played in fun and with jest, though, and it's an enjoyable time.

item.name: Saga
item.comment: With two players, there is a lot of take-that and back-and-forth. I know it is recommended with 4, and I need to try that before I make my final decision here. But overall it was a fun experience.

item.name: Saint Malo
item.comment: After one play, it's difficult to rate. I am worried that multiple plays will make it feel a little samey, and there wasn't that amazing UNNGH! to it like I feel with a similar game, Roll Through the Ages. Still, very creative use of spatial awareness and I like the dice mechanic used in this way.

item.name: Saint Petersburg
item.comment: I started out very unimpressed with Saint Petersburg, as I found the art hideous and the gameplay rather uninspiring. Well, a few more plays and I'm sold. I even find the art comical now. A favorite online experience. I guess one of the things that bug me about this one is that every turn there is something that you're "supposed" to be doing. I like a bit more randomness to my decisions.

item.name: Samarkand
item.comment: Neat little stock market game that reminds me of later designs. Sid Sackson was a true visionary and I have come to appreciate his games quite a bit.

item.name: Samurai
item.comment: A very good, beautifully-presented game by Knizia. I like the mechanics and the scoring reminds me of China/Web of Power. I came to the party late on this one but I imagine if I played it when it originally came out I would have been blown away at the ingenuity.

item.name: Samurai Battles
item.comment: Samurai Battles is another great Borg design -- unfortunately, it stops right there and doesn't surpass the rest of his designs in my mind. The mechanics are thematically and carry through well, but it might just be a combination of the theme and the gameplay, but it doesn't sing to me like the other iterations. Also, the minis are very, very fragile and difficult to play with. But a good try and if you're into this time period, this is a winner.

item.name: Samurai Spirit
item.comment: It's a solid co-op, but it didn't grab me for some reason. Everything about it screamed that I would love it.

item.name: San Juan
item.comment: After playing Race for the Galaxy, I actually enjoyed San Juan a bit more. Very simple to pick up and play, nice two-player game.

item.name: Say Anything
item.comment: A much better version of Apples to Apples. The scoring system is easy and simple to teach and understand, and being able to write out your own answers is so superior to A2A. It makes things a lot more fun and interesting. Great party game!

item.name: Scarab Lords
item.comment: Neat little tactical game in a deck of cards. Great option for two players. While you might be frustrated if you can't get the cards you need, it seems to be somewhat balanced by the special cards in the game. Good game!

item.name: Scattergories
item.comment: Scattergories is a good game. I think its got a bad rap over the years. It's not close to being a top choice as a party game, because I think party games should be a lot more raucous and fun, but it's still an entertaining word exercise.

item.name: The Scepter of Zavandor
item.comment: Much too long, but a good game none-the-less.

item.name: Schlacht am Buffet
item.comment: Clever use of cards and some neat components for this filler. Not something I'm going to search for because it's just very samey to other titles, but still fun to play.

item.name: Schotten-Totten
item.comment: It looks cooler, but Battle Line is probably the better game with the introduction of the extra cards. Played online only.

item.name: Scotland Yard
item.comment: We enjoy co-op/puzzle-type games and this was a winner as soon as we played it. I have to say, being Mr. X was a lot more fun than trying to find the slippery worm!

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment: An okay word game when played with friends and people who don't take it seriously.

item.name: Seasons
item.comment: The first few times I played Seasons, I was excited. It is fresh and beautiful, and it incorporates a Magic feel to the mechanics without making you play magic. It scales great from 2-4 as well. The only issue is that played with the wrong people, there is AP. I also haven't liked what I have read about the first expansion. Regardless, I'd still like a copy, because it's a fun and clever game.

item.name: The Secret of Monte Cristo
item.comment: There's a game here that I like and yet there isn't a lot of soul. That's a shame because the production is absolutely incredible. Those marbles are HEAVY and the mechanic is new to me and fresh. But the game just isn't GREAT. But it's fun, and I'd certainly give it another few plays.

item.name: Seeland
item.comment: An attractive euro, but nothing that makes me go crazy with love over. Happy to have played it though, and happy to play it again.

item.name: Sequence
item.comment: An okay diversion -- nothing more. Before I found BGG, this was a favorite of my wife and I.

item.name: Settlers of Catan
item.comment: 4th Edition. I played this a ton online before I "found" board games. I'll play but it's starting to show its age. There are other games I go to now for gateways, and sometimes I just can't get into the trading.

item.name: Shadow Hunters
item.comment: Sure, it has that variable-ending thing going for it, but the game itself is a ton of fun so I can look past it. A good Werewolf-style game that gives a variant on Werewolf and is a great party game.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: Especially fun with a good group, Shadows delivers a lot of excitement. Interesting that there might not be a traitor at all. A good challenge! Beautiful production. I feel like perhaps I am not enjoying the game as much as I first did, just because the effort that you put into an action sometimes feels like you're just doing something negative. But it's just such a gorgeous game it's hard for me to let go. *Update* - I'm letting go. Too long and not enough substance, and while the traitor element is fun it's just not as amazing as I want it to be.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: Merlin's Company
item.comment: A very simple expansion to incorporate and learn. Merlin himself doesn't do much, but the travel cards can really mess you up and the additional Witch cards are super evil. I don't see a big reason to buy this.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: Sir Bedivere, the 8th Knight
item.comment: A worthy addition to the Table -- I'm not sure if he adds anything completely super, but it's another good option to have and to pick from.

item.name: Shear Panic
item.comment: This one surprised me. A fun thematic abstract, the different layers of scoring was creative and thought-provoking, and I immediately wanted to play again. Of course, the sculpts make the game. Terrific little game.

item.name: Sheriff of Nottingham
item.comment: This is a solid game of bluffing that I enjoy playing, but I don't feel the need to own. The mechanics are clever and the way the Sheriff works is fantastic.

item.name: Sherlock Deluxe
item.comment: Okay memory game for kids, I'm terrible at it!

item.name: Shogun
item.comment: A euro wargame that works. The mechanisms make for an intriguing game, and the cube tower reallt sets it apart. One of the few epic games that I want in my collection.

item.name: Show Manager
item.comment: Not too huge of a fan of this one. Didn't seem like there was much to it in the way of strategy, and the theme did not get me one bit. Perhaps if the actors listed were real. To be fair, I didn't like Hollywood Blockbuster either, so maybe I just don't like this theme.

item.name: Skip-Bo
item.comment: Not really worth your time, there are much better card games.

item.name: Skittles
item.comment: Terrific big dexterity game -- a ton of fun.

item.name: Skull
item.comment: Fantastically-illustrated bluffing game that can handle a lot of people. It's quick and cute and I think it's a winner.

item.name: Skyline
item.comment: It's not a game that you want to necessarily pull off the shelf and get excited about. It IS a clever use of dice and a good filler.

item.name: Sleeping Queens
item.comment: Cute with just enough strategy for the kiddos. Terrific art.

item.name: Slide 5
item.comment: Eh, just seemed like a rather boring card game to me.

item.name: Small World
item.comment: My initial plays with 5 players left me rather blase, but I really want to play it with 2-3 and see if the smaller map brings more of an interest to me. I really WANT to love this game (as I do all Days of Wonder product).

item.name: Small World Underground
item.comment: I've been hard on Small World in the past -- but after playing Underground I have to admit that I'm starting to like it. Perhaps it's just starting to click with me, but Underground and it's theme really struck the right chord. Going to give Small World another chance for sure.

item.name: Smart Ass
item.comment: Well, it's not so great of a game. I think there was a laugh or two. Much better options out there.

item.name: Snake Oil
item.comment: I like Snake Oil probably more than I should. There's a few games that does this, but I like the theming of this one quite a bit.

item.name: Snow Tails
item.comment: One of my favorite race games, as there seems to be more decisions and future-planning to make than most race games. Then again, there's a good chance you're going to get ruined along the way -- no fun.

item.name: Sobek
item.comment: A fun experience but not sure if the game is memorable at all. Played two players and I'm thinking more would be better.

item.name: Soccer Tactics World
item.comment: First off, the best sports game I've played, hands down. To do soccer without dexterity and succeed is a success indeed. The game is fun, intuitive, easy to learn, and my son and I have had a BLAST with it. I am 0-2 so far, and enjoying it all the same.

item.name: Sorry!
item.comment: There are, at least, some movement decisions here. And the card-driven movement was, I'm sure, a big deal at the time. *Update* - I played this with my son and cousin the other day, and I realized it was broken. With the card pulls, it's entirely possible you could be playing Sorry! for your entire life, and also entirely possible that you never get a guy out of start. No good. Avoid!

item.name: Sorry! Sliders
item.comment: A good mix of a party/dexterity game. Another one of those games that I can't see anyone not liking.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment: Excellent fun -- it's really got it all. The best of the unique games on the market.

item.name: Space Cadets
item.comment: I wanted to love it ... but I guess it wasn't quite right for me. It just seemed to go a bit long. Love the concept and ideas, but two hours of flicking a disc or doing a mini-puzzle just wasn't engaging enough. Plus, there are turns that some folks won't be doing anything. Maybe if everyone could do ALL of their turns at the same time, it would speed it up. There was a lot of downtime and that's the part I wish would go away.

item.name: Space Cadets: Dice Duel
item.comment: Played 3x and I still feel like I don't have my head around everything involved here. The stopping and going doesn't work as fluidly as I'd like it to. But this is tons better than it's daddy.

item.name: Space Dealer
item.comment: I acquired two copies of this for 8-player action. Needless to say, it's not for everyone! But if I'm feeling like 30 minutes of chaotic action, here you go! *Update* - Turns out 8 players might be even more chaotic than even I desire. I'll keep the one copy as I enjoyed the 3-player game. *Update* - Played it 4-player, and it was fantastic. Really fun. Bumped by rating up to 9 because I enjoy it so much and because it's so freaking wacky.

item.name: Space Hop
item.comment: Good introduction to board games and you can learn a bit about space, too. I think my son has memorized the cards ... LOL!

item.name: Space Hulk (third edition)
item.comment: One of the best looking games I've ever seen along with being one of the most fun. THANKS BABE - what a great Christmas present!
item.conditiontext: Great condition. Opened, played several times. Everything is complete and intact.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game
item.comment: It a bit difficult to understand through the first play, but after the second the intensity and mechanics shined through. Very involving experience for a card game! Still, there's something missing thematically for me.

item.name: Spartacus: A Game of Blood & Treachery
item.comment: I might be rating this too high but I don't care. It was FUN. I like having fun playing games. It's probably not mechanically sound but who cares. It can create memorable moments in games and has the ability to do it twice a game.

item.name: Spartacus: Champions of House Batiatus Card Set
item.comment: These champions are nice to have as it helps to put a few more good gladiators in the market.

item.name: Spartacus: The Serpents and the Wolf Expansion Set
item.comment: To me, it's essential. The cards that it adds makes for a better experience. It also helps (or hurts, depending on your viewpoint) to make the base game more of a variable experience.

item.name: Specter Ops
item.comment: Usually I prefer the simple Scotland Yard when it comes to hidden movement games, but this was one of my favorites of the genre. I would definitely play again.

item.name: The Speicherstadt
item.comment: Terrific bidding game for 4-5. Very small amount of money to work with, so you have to watch closely what others are doing and make your decisions based off of that. Clever mechanics and with such a short play time and teachability, I really love it. It's sometimes just so agonizing, which makes it so fun! Beware, not a two-player game!

item.name: Splendor
item.comment: A good set-collection game. Nice components. No theme to speak of. But some clever mechanics here, just no real staying power in my eye.

item.name: Spyfall
item.comment: I'm not sure what I expecting here, but games like this one usually go over my head and I'm left to wonder why they are so popular. I guess they're not for me, but I'll play when asked since others enjoy it so much.

item.name: Stadium Checkers
item.comment: Goodness, I remember this one. An ingenious design for the time, but I still don't like the game and I never did.

item.name: Star Trek: Catan
item.comment: Honestly, I wasn't expecting much, but they did a good job with this one. Real pretty game, and I enjoyed what they did with the roles. I'd play this anytime.

item.name: Star Trek: Expeditions
item.comment: I enjoyed it for the theme and for the plays I got from it, but unfortunately after the first three plays things started feeling stale. I would have been excited about the expansion but it is way too expensive and you get a pittance. Knizia does have a bit of a problem going thematic.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault
item.comment: It took me 10 plays before I began to write this comment. The main reason for that is twofold: 1) How can I describe correctly enough what might be my favorite merge of all time (Descent/Star Wars) 2) What do I do with Descent? So that's my problem here -- I'm afraid that Imperial Assault has somehow replaced my beloved Descent, and I don't know how to react to that. I just know that I really love playing Imperial Assault! Excellent, better-crafted campaign. Fantastic minis that look great painted up. Two different games in one box that are both excellent. Seriously, the two-player Skirmish out of the box is really well done! So for now, I'm all in, and we'll see where this goes.

item.name: Star Wars: The Queen's Gambit
item.comment: I have to thank ATTICUS for hooking me up with a play on this bad boy. Such a creative system invented for this one, that truly mimics the great end of Episode 1. The mechanics are spot on and really make this feel like a unique, epic game, which is exactly the way it should feel. Would love to grab a copy and play it once a year, because that's what it is, it's an experience game and it needs to be experienced and enjoyed.

item.name: Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game
item.comment: Beautiful ships, but the gameplay didn't strike me too strong. I don't really care for the vanilla game with just moving and shooting, and the advanced rules seem to make things just too difficult for me to enjoy the system. Which is a shame, because I love SW.

item.name: Starfarers of Catan
item.comment: So happy to have a chance to play this -- it's a component whore's dream! Very entertaining game as well, if it was a bit shorter I would never play Settlers again. Really enjoyed the thematic look and feel of the game. Catan in space adds a lot of great ideas to the franchise, and the goober in this game is ULTRA cool. I seriously love the components and I really like the gameplay as well. The only downer is the time, especially when you add in the expansion. Still, I'd play again in a heartbeat.

item.name: Starfarers of Catan: 5-6 Player Expansion
item.comment: The "sticky" additions to the board is terrific, but I'm afraid that the game goes quite a bit longer with the added players. So as fun and cool as it looks, perhaps this should just stay at a max 4.

item.name: Start Player
item.comment: A neat alternative to the regular methods. Not much to it, though.

item.name: Steampunk Rally
item.comment: Two players it was fun, I'd love to try with multiples and see if it's more fun!

item.name: Steel Driver
item.comment: The game works just fine, but I wasn't inspired by the play at all. Not really my type of game, although I do like some other stock market games, this one just wasn't clicking with me. And the bland presentation did not help.

item.name: Stomple
item.comment: Gorgeous production and a surprisingly-fun abstract that I think will do very well.

item.name: Stone Age
item.comment: Easy entry, very teachable, beautiful in every way, every game different. I love it!

item.name: Stone Age: The Expansion
item.comment: Style adds some new wrinkles and in some ways, the game feels almost like a different one. The new card acquisition space that uses decorations to obtain cards is a busy spot, and I really like the addition of the style board. I could go either way on the 5th player, it is nice to have but it does make the game a bit longer. This would have gotten a 7.5 but they folded the board wrong, and now there's a nice crease in it. That really takes away from the beautiful art of the game. Why even use a folded board? Very poor thought there.

item.name: Stone Age: The New Huts
item.comment: Good to have if you love the game like I do. Variety is the spice of life.

item.name: Strasbourg
item.comment: Feld is a true star. Strasbourg is a neat mix of bidding and completing personal goals, something that I really liked in Metropolys. Terrific game that's so new and different feeling. Hope it gets over here soon!

item.name: Strat-O-Matic Baseball
item.comment: Thanks David for the gift! It's a baseball fan's dream, you're right. Wish I had it 20 years ago.

item.name: Stratego
item.comment: I used to find this game fascinating, but I just can't find the interest to play it anymore. *update* - new edition bought for 5 bucks, and I found the special powers quite neat.

item.name: Straw
item.comment: Oh, no. Not my cup of tea. Just feel like I'm playing cards to play em. Not seeing a strategy here.

item.name: Streetcar
item.comment: This is one of those games that I know is pretty good, but that I'm just horrible at. Now, even if I was good at it, it's not my favorite design in the world. But it's easy to learn and a good idea.

item.name: String Railway: Transport
item.comment: I give the designer a lot of credit for some creativity, but laying down strings and trying to deliver cubes is just not going to work right in my mind. The long routes were very difficult to obtain and the overall feel from the table was that it was too long for what it is.

item.name: Suburbia
item.comment: Played the app. Did not care for the game. Ugly and Castles does a better job.

item.name: Summoner Wars
item.comment: Quite possibly one of the best card games I've played. You can almost SEE the miniatures out there fighting. Four players might not be recommended, though, as it takes the game a bit longer than what it should be. Still, incredible depth with simple rules almost always makes a game great to me.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Cloaks Faction Deck
item.comment: The Cloaks are such a deceiving army. At first glance, their units don't seem as powerful as others, but where they get you is their versatility. The summoner is extremely versatile, and the event cards and heroes these guys can put out there can really fluster and psychologically get to you. I've thrown several armies against them and I've either lost or barely won each time. Great, balanced army!

item.name: Summoner Wars: Grungor's Charge Reinforcement Pack
item.comment: One of the best reinforcement packs ever produced, almost all of these extra units are usable and exciting to play with, for both armies. I especially enjoy the catapults, the rune dwarf, and the Goblin heroes.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Guild Dwarves vs Cave Goblins
item.comment: The first thing I'll mention on these is that I love how the traditional outlook of these races are used quite differently in the game. Sure, the goblins stick pretty close to the "rushing, sneaking goblins" that we usually see, but those armies in other games usually get squashed to bits. In SW, the goblins are a blast to play and they do quite well. The Dwarves focus on destroying walls and they have plenty of heavy hitters and good shields to do it. The distinct feel of both armies is terrific and there's so many different strategies to use when combined with the reinforcement deck. The best of the two starter packs, by far. Logging my plays under main heading Summoner Wars.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Jungle Elves Faction Deck
item.comment: Jungle Elves are a blast to play, although with the high cost of all their cards it can be difficult to field a competitive army at all times. But it's a fun challenge and they're a very interesting and thematic army.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Master Set
item.comment: The Master Set is a fantastic jumping-on place for the series, and to boot you get a real board with it. Fantastic product. Logging my plays under main heading Summoner Wars.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Phoenix Elves vs Tundra Orcs
item.comment: I'll just say I'm not a big fan of the elves. But the Tundra Orcs are one of my favorite armies in the game. Great variety and fun to play with. Terrific art. I know that others enjoy the elves, so with that caveat, this is a must-buy set. Logging my plays under main heading Summoner Wars.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Rukar's Power Reinforcements Pack
item.comment: Great pack full of fun for the Orcs. I don't play the elves very much, but there's some good ideas here, just not as great as some of the other packs.

item.name: Summoner Wars: The Filth Faction Deck
item.comment: The first thing that I love about The Filth is how different and fun they are to play. The mutant plays are great fun and always surprising to the opponent, and there's a lot of flexibility in the ways you can play the army. One of the stronger armies I've seen so far. The summoner is good, too, being able to build magic quite easily every turn if you work it right. Great deck!

item.name: Sumo Ham Slam
item.comment: Honestly, if you're looking to have a lot of fun, this game fits the bill quite well. The components are well-done and kids have a BLAST with it!

item.name: Sun, Sea & Sand
item.comment: One of the best thematic euros I've played in a long while. With more plays my rating would certainly go up. It's on the heavier side of what I like but it was lots of fun regardless with good future planning elements and worker placement. *Update* - with the second play in the books, the game became much easier to understand and I actually enjoy the future-planning aspect quite a bit.

item.name: Sunken City
item.comment: Another clever theme tied into a mechanic. Plays well 2-4 players. Have enjoyed it so far. *Update* Just don't see it getting out very much anymore.

item.name: Surf's Up, Dude!
item.comment: I'm surprised to see the low rating on this. I wasn't blown away by it or anything, but the production is top-notch and the game is okay. I did play it with a surfer, though, so maybe I had a better time than playing with the average geek.

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis!
item.comment: Absolutely awesome fun. I never got a chance to play Survive! when I was a kid, and that's a shame, because I'm positive I would have enjoyed it very much. I haven't seen the old version, but the new one is FANTASTIC. It's a gorgeous game to look at and really pleasing to the eye. But above all, the entire family had a great time escaping to the outer islands, pleading and begging not to be eaten by sharks, and capsizing their parents boats (grumble grumble ...) This will win Reprint of the Year, and Stronghold Games is to be commended for such great work. I rate Survive! a 7 for now, but it's one of those games that I think will grow in rating over time, opposed to drop. *Update* - played with the squids, and yep, the game is now an 8.

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis! The Giant Squid Mini Expansion
item.comment: The Squid gives you more options, which is good. He's also quite powerful, which depending on which side of the coin you're on, is bad.

item.name: Ta Yü
item.comment: A bit too abstract and long to us -- more of an exercise of work than fun. But beautiful game and components for sure and I can see the appeal to a more abstract set of mind.

item.name: Taboo
item.comment: The old classic rears its head from time to time at family gatherings. Good for a laugh now and then. The main problem is that I seem to be either good or horrible at it, depending on the day. I have a bigger tendency to "shut down" at this game than other word games out there. I really prefer Time's Up and Catchphrase to Taboo.

item.name: Take It or Leave It
item.comment: Numbers and scoring. Good way to waste time? That's about all I can say. IT's a game, but not a good one.

item.name: Takenoko
item.comment: GORGEOUS, really fun action-selection/secret goal game. Turns are quick and the scoring goals have a neat ebb-and-flow to them. Bauza continues to impress me ...

item.name: Tako Judo
item.comment: What a terrific theme. Unfortunately, the game is just not as exciting as I would have hoped. There's something here somewhere, and perhaps it should be just a two-player game -- but with four players it was just too chaotic and restricted.

item.name: Tales of the Arabian Nights
item.comment: Hahah, well -- I'm not sure how much of a game this is. Whoever wins or loses doesn't seem to be that important or rely on much skill. It's a storytelling game and the fun part is whatever happens during the game. At the end, it was fun going over what happened to each of us -- myself, a battle in the magical beast wars, and my son married to the sexy daughter of a beautiful princess. I can't imagine playing it more than a few times, however -- it is fun for the occasional entertainment.

item.name: Talisman (Revised 4th Edition)
item.comment: It felt like I could literally go around in circles for 10 hours and never get to an ending point. Not a fan. For a thematic adventure feel, I'd much rather sit down to Runebound knowing that there is indeed an end in sight and I can do at least a little to control it.

item.name: Tally Ho!
item.comment: Pretty good little abstract disguised in a great theme. There's a fair bit of luck in turning over the tiles, but that also makes it very replayable. It's also cool that you have to play both sides in a game. While the luck can make some situations very frustrating, it's enjoyable enough for a quick two-player game. Played online at Yucata.de.

item.name: Taluva
item.comment: My track record with abstracts is poor. But this game is just a blast to look at and play. *Update* - after collecting dust for over a year, got to pull it out again and realized why I liked this game so much in the past. Just an excellent, fast-playing tile-laying game with a lot of choices and fun. Absolutely gorgeous.

item.name: Tapple
item.comment: Tapple is a fun game, very underrated for friends and family. And I wonder what might happen with some adults playing on a late night?

item.name: Telestrations
item.comment: Excellent party game, definitely in my Top 3. The concept is genius and lends itself to a ton of laughs. The flipping whiteboards in this makes the purchase a necessity.

item.name: Telestrations: 12 Player Party Pack
item.comment: Excellent party game, definitely in my Top 3. The concept is genius and lends itself to a ton of laughs. The flipping whiteboards in this makes the purchase a necessity. x12!

item.name: Terror in Meeple City
item.comment: So if you like dexterity games, this is the one to get. Fantastic production and design. Love the art. Mr. Bauza, I am a slave for you.

item.name: Thebes
item.comment: So far I've only played with two, and I'm anxious to see how it flows with 3-4. For now, it's a keeper just because it's so different than anything else I have. I'm also a sucker for ancient Egyptian themes.

item.name: There's a Moose in the House
item.comment: 4-and-up will enjoy this one and to be honest, I kind of enjoy it too. :) Excellent game for little kids!

item.name: Through the Desert
item.comment: Best with 3. One of the few abstracts in my collection I never see getting traded away. *Update* How was I supposed to know Kingdom Builder would come along?

item.name: Thunderstone
item.comment: Uh oh - I didn't have high expectations going in, but yikes. It's just way too mathy, it certainly is not elegant by any stretch of the imagination. I'm not sure why this is so popular -- I had a really hard time even desiring to finish my first play. If I ever play it again we'll see if something went wrong, but I was playing with experienced players and I just didn't see where the fun was. *UPDATE* Played two-player with my son and we thought it was a lot better than the last time. With the starting setup of monsters and items things flowed a lot better. I have no idea if they had some expansion thrown into the other game but this was a lot more varied and interesting. We got through the game fine but it was a bit long.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment: Another great euro in that it's so easy to learn how to play and you just want to pick it up and play it again right there. Great presentation and neat mechanics that remind me of TTR. Plays great with 2-4. Love it.

item.name: Tichu
item.comment: Fun blend of some trick-taking games that I enjoyed growing up. Only playable with four, and with that number, it's really quite fun and terrific. To me, putting a certain number of points on the line before you start playing (calling Tichu) really makes the game!

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: What a game -- great with any number, my wife loves it, introduced over 10 new gamers to it. Online version rules. What more to say? At this point, I am only playing with the Mega rules.

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 1 – Team Asia & Legendary Asia
item.comment: What a great start to the map expansion series. Both maps are terrific and very different. The Legendary map introduces a new strategy, destroying trains, and it's a welcome addition to the family. The map is tightly designed and plays well. The team map, showing predominantly China, is a HUGE winner! So far with my plays with four people the game is very tense and exhilarating. The trick is that some of the information is shared, but not all, so it really makes you think how you want to move and plan. I didn't think the map would play very tight either, but we found ourselves fighting over several spots with no stations to share them. Great expansion! Thanks Jasmine for the Christmas present!

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 2 – India & Switzerland
item.comment: Switzerland is my favorite two-player map. Just so well done. Have played online many, many times. Yet to try India?

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 3 – The Heart of Africa
item.comment: Nothing truly exciting here, in my opinion. It seemed more of a chore to collect the extra cards than fun.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Alvin & Dexter
item.comment: Honestly, it's better than I thought it would be. Adds a lot of fun and good tactics to TTR. Can't wait to paint em up!

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europa 1912
item.comment: The depos/warehouses are a fun variant, but certainly not essential to gameplay. I do love the extra routes, though. And Big Cities makes the board so confrontational -- play it with the depos and it's a mad dash for single routes!

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europe
item.comment: My, I love this game. The "advanced" mechanics just bring the system into a brand new light and make the ownership of locomotive cards a really big deal. The map design is just genius and creates so much conflict. My favorite of the TTRs to date.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Märklin
item.comment: I view Marklin as the ugly stepchild of the Ticket series, and I don't know why. I think I just place it so far away from the rest of the series due to the passenger mechanic. But guess what? I still love it, and it provides a different experience that I enjoy very much!

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Nordic Countries
item.comment: It felt like a miniature version of Europe, which is just too cool. Two players was quick and good, waiting on three.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Switzerland
item.comment: Just a terrific option for two players! Love the variety and the up-front nature of this map. Have played this a ton online.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: The Card Game
item.comment: Rather disappointed in that it could (and probably should) have been themed and marketed differently. Going in with the TTR name gave me different expectations. The game itself is okay, but the memorization of route cards and a few of the mechanics didn't give me enjoyment.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: USA 1910
item.comment: Essential expansion to TTR - love it. I use the Mega version every game but Big Cities is also terrific.

item.name: Tide of Iron: Next Wave
item.comment: Clever system, awesome components. Not sure how much I want to play this type of game, but it's very nicely done.

item.name: Tikal
item.comment: Tikal is a beautiful game and it is also quite thematic, which gives it a big thumb in my book. Fortunately, the fine folk that introduced me to it were not big into analysis paralysis, because this must be the game that spawned the concept. I actually do like the mechanics of it, but what would inspire a designer to give each player ten actions a turn?! Can't wait to play again.

item.name: Tiki Topple
item.comment: Very clever game and mechanic -- definitely useful with the kids in teaching them bluffing and strategy. I have to say that I'm really enjoying this game -- one of the best games in the kids aisle.

item.name: Timber Tom
item.comment: Incredible production, really a lot of eye candy and it's nice to put on the table. The game itself is okay -- it works and it's fun, and there's always going to be a close finish.

item.name: Timber Tom: The Wollemi Pines
item.comment: Good looking trees and a good mechanic for the game. The designer was nice enough to include a copy in the base game for free.

item.name: Time's Up! Deluxe
item.comment: Great fun, but I like Title Recall better.

item.name: Time's Up! Title Recall!
item.comment: My absolute favorite party game. I really enjoy the second stage of this game, where you're just giving one word clues for the answers that you are expected to know by then! Jasmine and I are great at it, too! *Update* - 10 plays through and it's an absolute gem. Love it love it.

item.name: Timeline: Inventions
item.comment: The game itself is nothing to write home about and is certainly not heavy. The only reason it's on my wishlist is that I think it would be a fantastic learning tool for everyone that played it.

item.name: Tiny Epic Kingdoms
item.comment: This fell flat for me. I feel like the designer tried to put a bigger game in a small package. Yes, I understand that was the intent, but if I'm going to play a big game I want to play a big game.

item.name: Tobago
item.comment: A bit underwhelmed as a first play, and those cursed treasures might aid to giving you a bad taste in your mouth. But the game is absolutely gorgeous, and there's some clever deduction mechanics here. Definitely would like to try again. *Update* - better with four playres.

item.name: Toc Toc Woodman: Golden Axe Expansion
item.comment: LOL, it's an extra axe. Why am I including this in my owned games, anyway? I appreciate the extra axe, though, and it's gold! Woohoo!

item.name: Toc Toc Woodman: Golden Core and Bark Promo
item.comment: I'll go as far as to say that the gold core and bark are a big deal and should be included in every set.

item.name: Tokaido
item.comment: Tokaido is just another Bauza masterpiece. It's clever and gorgeous, with some interesting decisions throughout.

item.name: Torres
item.comment: Full disclosure -- I thought I wouldn't like this game. Surprise! It was fun. It's got the action points going and there's no conflict at all, but there's still creative ways to have fun and score points. Board looks beautiful afterward as well. I have enjoyed the plays but not enough to feel the need to keep it around.

item.name: Toss Your Cookies
item.comment: My kids didn't really care for it. Neither do the adults.

item.name: A Touch of Evil 'The Allies' Supplement
item.comment: I didn't really see much of a difference with these cards in the deck.

item.name: A Touch of Evil ‘The Madness' Game Supplement
item.comment: New cards mix into the game well, provide more options.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: The Supernatural Game
item.comment: The experience is okay. I think that the co-op game is much better than the competitive game (and makes more thematic sense). But what it comes down to is that there isn't many decisions to make, and the big decision of the game (when to fight the bad guy) can be reached in awkward or strange conditions. Most of the game consists of rolling a die, pulling a card, rolling a die, pulling a card, and it gets a bit monotonous even with the theme there. I DO really like the mechanic with the town elders being friend or foe and having to peek at that information. I just wish the game was more streamlined overall.

item.name: Tower of Babel
item.comment: I have to say, I wasn't expecting much with this, but it turned out to be better than I thought. The blind selection part gave me pause, but it worked out better than I thought it would. The theme is just pasted on, but at least you could try to think you're building things. Anyway, the area majority saved it for me, and it's something I'd like to play again.

item.name: Trajan
item.comment: One of the things I like about Feld is that he puts a lot of different ideas in a game and gives you lots of different ways to win. Trajan is a good game, but I feel like it might be a little *too* convoluted with ideas and mechanics. I think I prefer his "simpler" designs, like Luna or Castles of Burgundy, although I enjoyed my play of Trajan.

item.name: TransAmerica
item.comment: Plays terrific with six and takes 30 minutes. These are the kinds of games everyone should own. I look forward to getting a copy and really glad I had a chance to experience it. Easy to teach and enjoy.

item.name: Trias
item.comment: A bit too abstract for what I was looking for. Scoring seems a bit fiddly to me and doesn't flow the way I would like. The quality of the components is less than what I had hoped, also.

item.name: Tribune: Primus Inter Pares
item.comment: Tribune -- a worker-placement game (yay!) with a Roman theme (yay!) that unfortunately does not deliver as big a punch as I had hoped (boo). A fine game and I would play it again, but it lacks the excitement I was hoping for from all the hype.

item.name: Triumvirate
item.comment: Having recently played this and Filipino Fruit Market, it's very encouraging and refreshing to see these trick-taking games that are breaking the mold and really making things interesting in the genre. It takes a few plays to really understand what you're doing in this, but it's a very enjoyable two-player game.

item.name: Trollhalla
item.comment: Trollhalla is a great family game that I would probably have bought four years ago. These days, I already have a dearth of family games and this one doesn't quite reach the level of those. Certainly up for another play anytime, but not a favorite just yet. Great art and a fun theme, though.

item.name: Tsuro
item.comment: I like games that can handle a lot of people as much as anyone, but I've seen better options than this. Beautiful pieces, though.

item.name: Tumblin-Dice
item.comment: Who cares if it's almost completely luck-based? This is a heck of a lot of fun! Terrific production and a gorgeous almost art-like feel of the board makes it fun to play and look at.

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment: I can see why this one is so popular. Excellent cardplay and a deep historical simulation makes it shine. Of course, it is not the best board game in the world. But it does a great job simulating the cold war and influencing areas. A bit too heavy for my taste, though.

item.name: Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star
item.comment: There's no strategy here, but honestly, the components are so awesome and cute and my daughter loves it so that I have to rate it this way.

item.name: Two by Two
item.comment: Pretty good family strategy game with a very nice production. It was an enjoyable experience and I'd like to have a copy sometime. *Update* - have since acquired a copy and after a few plays, there's just not as much fun here as I originally thought. What's worse is the kids aren't enjoying it -- perhaps too abstract for them?

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar
item.comment: Probably one of my highest-rated euros. Theme, presentation, and mechanics, this one ticks all the right boxes. It's a bit long, but this game deserves it. I'll never be a master at it but I'll enjoy playing it for years to come. Happy birthday to me!

item.name: U-Build Monopoly
item.comment: Well, it's Monopoly. But I will say that this version did a good job in making it different, and taking care of two problems I had with the game: player elimination and length. Once a player is eliminated the game ends, and if you make a short track the game won't last more than an hour. Still, it's Monopoly. Not sure what to say. It wasn't bad!

item.name: Ubongo
item.comment: No doubt my favorite series of puzzle games, the original Ubongo is just terrific -- although I am finding Ubongo Extreme to be my more favorite of the two. *Update* - with the 5-6 player expansion, Ubongo has now moved into 10 territory.

item.name: Ubongo 3D
item.comment: This game is just SILLY hard. I had a real tough time with it and I'm not sure I completed one puzzle. My wife, on the other hand, took to it immediately and did well. Not sure what that means, but looking forward to adding a copy so she can beat me some more. Component quality is stupendous!

item.name: Ubongo Extreme
item.comment: Thanks babe - great birthday present! Extreme is my favorite Ubongo to date -- it's just a lot of fun, and the gem-collecting is a bit better IMO.

item.name: Ubongo: Die Erweiterung für 5-6 Spieler
item.comment: Terrific expansion, so glad I have it! Ubongo up to 6 players now, and everything is seamlessly incorporated. Nicely done and yay!

item.name: Ubongo: Duel
item.comment: I finally won one! This is a tough one for sure. My wife is the Ubongo Queen around here. I wish the boards and pieces were of better quality, though, as it really pales in comparison to its brethren and takes down the enjoyment for me by a notch or two.

item.name: Ugg-Tect
item.comment: I had high hopes for this one. Unfortunately the game sputters because of the different words and phrases that need to be learned and said quickly. If these words were easy to remember it would be one thing, but you have to quickly check between the helper card and the situation in order to say the right thing, and then the builder has to check and figure it out. It would seem to be a lot better just grunting. I had high hopes!

item.name: Undermining
item.comment: A fresh theme and some neat mechanics make this a winner. The only thing holding it back for me is replayability, it seems that the game would be a bit samey after a while. But the idea of upgrading your drill and the variable setup and component quality makes it a blast to play.

item.name: Unpublished Prototype
item.comment: 1) Hex on the Beach -- a very light card game about making drinks. Needs some major tweaking as there just weren't many decisions in it at all. 2) B-57 Cooperative Realtime Game -- a fast, realtime card game where you have forward and rear gunners playing cards to take out planes. Creative ideas and it reminded me a bit of Wok Star. Perhaps a bit monotonous but it's so quick that wouldn't matter.

item.name: Urbion
item.comment: It lacked the pop of Onirim. The art is still great and unique, but Onirim is what I'm going to compare it too, I have no choice, and it is just not as good

item.name: Utopia
item.comment: FANTASTIC production but the game just doesn't flow the way I feel like it should. Would play again but have no interest in buying this one. There's several fiddly rules included too.

item.name: Valdora
item.comment: Quick actions, good decision making, beautiful presentation. Love it!

item.name: Vegas Showdown
item.comment: Great theme and with some upgraded components, this is a huge hit. I already like auctions a lot and building a casino hotel is a really engaging game. Really liked how the cards came out and put things unable to be bid on, and loved the decisions very much.

item.name: Vikings
item.comment: Great with 2-4 players and awesome production. I really enjoy the different decisions you have to make between the building of the islands and where/when you place your vikings -- awesome to have these things that have to work together for victory. Fun, light euro that I think I'll always enjoy! *Update* - Moved into the 9 territory after a quick, awesome play over Thanksgiving in which all four players knew how to play. The game took less than 45 minutes.

item.name: Villa Paletti
item.comment: Fun dexterity game - not much to it, but a lot of fun to set out for family gatherings and game days.

item.name: Village
item.comment: One of the better worker placement games to come along in a bit in my opinion. Village's death mechanic I find fascinating, and I love the idea of disposing of people to score at the right time. I think this one is going to be a favorite for a long time to come. And I'm going to black marker the numbers on there to get rid of the stickers. *Update* - Unfortunately, the game felt a little stale in future plays. I liked it to begin with, though, and will retain my 7.5 rating. I would play it again, but I don't feel like owning it anymore.

item.name: Volle Scholle
item.comment: For a deck of cards and 10 minutes, this is a neat little blend of a game. I like the mechanic that encourages you to lose auctions in order to build population. I would love to see that incorporated in a bigger game.

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion
item.comment: I'm not much of a CCG or LCG person, but I have to admit that this is a good system. Both times I enjoyed playing, although like most card games that rely on the draw, it's a bit difficult to enjoy if you're not getting what you want.

item.name: Wasabi!
item.comment: One of the best productions I've seen. Game is a lot of fun too -- especially with two players. At four players it gets to be a bit difficult to strategize when it comes back around to your turn. But the mechanics are fun and easy to understand and teach.

item.name: Weapons & Warriors Castle Storm / Pirate Clash Game
item.comment: We enjoyed this more than the base set, mostly because of the pirate ship! All in all, a fun activity for kids and adults who like to be kids, too. Forget the rules of the game and just have fun shooting the targets. I will say that the game is made quite well, the use of the rubber bands is genius and creates a really fun experience.

item.name: Weapons & Warriors: Castle Combat Set
item.comment: Eh -- it looks a lot more fun than it is to play. Very difficult to aim and get that terrific shot. More of a toy than a game. The rules of the game are poor, also. We enjoy the pirate/castle version much more than this one.

item.name: Web of Power
item.comment:
There's big-time scoring differences here between China and Web of Power, and I *think* I like China better. Other than the scoring, the games are almost identical in my mind. I do like the 'look' of China better, so it gets the better score.
*Update* - definitely like China better. I prefer the one-time scoring instead of Web's 2x, it's nice to have three cards out to see. And I like the map better, too. It just seems to play smoother. Clear winner.

item.name: Welcome to the Dungeon
item.comment: Clever push-your-luck action. Nicely produced game.

item.name: Werewolf
item.comment: I am tracking my Werewolf plays under the game "Werewolves of Miller Hollow".

item.name: The Werewolves of Miller's Hollow
item.comment: With a group of close friends/family it's a 9, with others that I don't know, a 6. Can't beat this at family or friend gatherings. I can't even guess how many times I played this growing up and at college.

item.name: What Would Jesus Do?
item.comment: A nice idea in theory, but you're ultimately looking at a roll-and-move game on a board that harkens of Candyland, with a pile of really messed-up mechanics. Presenting the real-life situations to kids is nice, but you would have to modify the rules greatly to make the game playable.

item.name: Which Witch?
item.comment: Finnish version. I've really enjoyed playing this with the kids this season and I expect to keep enjoying it for years to come.

item.name: White Elephant
item.comment: Probably a great game to play with non-gamers at a party. Not a big fan of the presentation.

item.name: Why Did the Chicken...?
item.comment: Apples to Apples variant that involves writing. In a very similar boat to Say Anything, so your enjoyment of the game depends a lot on the creativity of the people you play against.

item.name: Wings of War: Famous Aces
item.comment: Excellent system for plane battles, in fact, I can't imagine it being implemented in a better way.

item.name: Wings of War: Fire from the Sky
item.comment: I'm not much of a fan of the system to begin with, but this version with its subtle changes just didn't seem as good as WWI.

item.name: Winner's Circle
item.comment: My favorite horses are the ones that you can get that one, big jump on -- of course, usually they don't do too hot, but I'm all about the big blast. Anyway, a fun game that plays up to 6, but I think 4 might be the sweet spot.

item.name: Witch's Brew
item.comment: Solid little role-selection game in the style of Citadels, but with better-defined point scoring and things to do. Clever in its execution and the way points are collected.

item.name: Wits & Wagers
item.comment: Pretty good party game, as long as you play for the experience and not for the win. Clever and easy-to-teach mechanic. *Update* - believe it or not, I tend to enjoy Wits & Wagers Family a bit better.

item.name: Wits & Wagers Family
item.comment: I actually prefer this scoring system to the regular edition. In the original, it just seemed like people would hold onto their money until the 6th round, and then if they were clearly behind, blow it all and then who knows. The only negative with this game is that it is limited to five guessers, and that there aren't hardly enough questions.

item.name: Wiz-War (eighth edition)
item.comment: I went in with zero expectations and came out quite impressed! The components are stellar but its the gameplay that I was worried about -- and it really shines. It's a race game with a lot of fun thrown in along the way. If there was some way to eliminate player elimination (I really dislike that mechanic) it would be a purchase.

item.name: Wok Star
item.comment: Realtime cooperative action! What's not to like? Really enjoyed my first play and can't wait to get a copy.

item.name: Word on the Street Junior
item.comment: Excellent introductory word game for kids. My 5-year-old has great fun working on his spelling and adults have a great time with it too. Works just fine for adults as well.

item.name: World Conquerors
item.comment: A quick, leader-bashing win the world game. Some neat ideas as far as having leaders from all time-periods and having them run roughshod over the globe. It was designed to be quick and fast-paced and it is, and it is fun, but I wish that you could use the ruler's powers just a bit longer before you had to discard him. Definitely would enjoy another play.

item.name: World of Warcraft Miniatures Game
item.comment: I liked it to start -- but all the different character combinations and numbers on the card to memorize, along with the annoying U-base, really sucked the life out of me.

item.name: World of Warcraft: The Adventure Game
item.comment: It's a shorter version of Runebound, but the end-game conditions are so random and odd. I don't like ending a game when I feel like I'm in the middle of it. And while I'm bitching, the board is way too busy and hard to locate places. Unless you're a diehard fan of the online game, buy Runebound.

item.name: World Without End
item.comment: I want to like this game a lot -- the card mechanism is really ingenious, and I love how it drives the game. There were just a few times during the game that I planned for things to happen and they didn't happen. That led to a few turns that I couldn't do anything. Perhaps I just have to go into it thinking that they might not, and then I won't feel so disappointed. Even so, all the scores were close and it was a beautiful presentation.

item.name: WWE Superstar Showdown
item.comment: Very unique game and conglomeration of mechanics. If you're going to make a tactical wrestling game, this is the best it's going to get. I'd love to try a three or four-player variant before making a final decision on this. In the two-player game, it was fast and fun, but I'm not sure there's much replay value here.

item.name: Xia: Legends of a Drift System
item.comment: Hard to rate after one play, but I wasn't a huge fan of the open-endedness of the system and a lot of randomness that you don't have control of. Usually that's okay if the story is chugging along, but I felt like I was "drifting in space" most of the time and it just didn't work for me.

item.name: Xiangqi
item.comment: This is a better game than chess. I like the river down the center, and each piece is a neat twist. Also quite thematic -- a solid abstract.

item.name: Yahtzee
item.comment: You know, a game of Yahtzee with wife or son is sometimes right up my alley. It must be the dice.

item.name: Yahtzee Free for All
item.comment: Getting to be a bit boring for me just after a few plays. I'm not sure what it is, but sometimes I feel like I would rather just play the original Yahtzee. Perhaps with the increased options I just feel like the tension is gone.

item.name: Yggdrasil
item.comment: It was an okay co-op ... LOVE the art, but the actual game I wasn't going crazy over. It had a feel of Ghost Stories to it, but I was missing the visual element a bit. Just having the enemies go up and down the track was not engaging enough for me. Still, I'd play it again and enjoy it, but it's not a keeper in my view.

item.name: You Can't Check Me!: The Basketball Card Game
item.comment: It's completely luck-driven, ugly, and it might be broken. But for some reason, I must admit I had a little bit of fun playing with my 7-year-old. But yikes -- it truly is the definition of "brainless filler".

item.name: You're Bluffing!
item.comment: It's fun, and I love bluffing games, but perhaps it goes on a bit long for what it is. Still fun and still in for a few more plays.

item.name: Yspahan
item.comment: I like how it handles 2-4 players. Always enjoy seeing new ways to incorporate dice into games. A lot of fun to play, perhaps someday I will figure out the strategy so I can win one of these times! *Update* - I've figured out the strategy and won a few times! Wonderful game and terrific euro.

item.name: Zendo
item.comment: Here's a good example of a good game that I don't necessarily like. It's mental, and it's spacial, but I'm not going to be attracted to it any time soon. Still, if you love it and love these types of games, more power to you. It's quality.

item.name: Zeus on the Loose
item.comment: Ladder-type numbers game -- I thought it would go over better with the kids, but they're not real fans of it.

item.name: Zimbbos!
item.comment: Stacking fun. Great components.

item.name: Zombicide
item.comment: I saw a lot of absence of choice and not enough variation from scenarios. Maybe I got the wrong impression from the first play, but I do not desire a second.

item.name: Zombie Dice
item.comment: Very light, push-your-luck game that has been a hit so far in that "mindless filler" category. Figures that a game about eating brains would be mindless! Really a lot of fun.

item.name: Zombie in my Pocket
item.comment: I acquired this in a mystery box, played it a few times, and sent it off. It doesn't really hold my interest.

item.name: Zombies!!!
item.comment: Quite uninteresting, and the art is straight gory. Not my kind of thing.

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment: Uh-oh! After 9 plays it's waning a bit for me. Still a solid 8 on the scale, and I still enjoy it, but it just seems a little repetitious at times. I never expect it to leave the collection, though. It's a wonderful-looking game with a lot of appeal to families. UPDATE: I played once with two of the expansions and that helped liven it up a bit, so that's good news.

item.name: Zooloretto: Rio Grande Games Expansion Pack #1
item.comment: The petting zoo and extra enclosures add some surprising variety!

item.name: Zooloretto: The Dice Game
item.comment: It works fine and was fun for a diversion, but nothing more to stand on. It's big brother is the better devotion of time.

item.name: Zoowaboo
item.comment: Neat ways to put higher mechanics (push your luck, bidding, puzzling) in a kids game.

item.name: Zpocalypse
item.comment: I feel like this rating is too high, but the company I played with helped its cause. A little fiddly and just doesn't work as well as other games in the genre.
